reviewText:
As a avid player of the tabletop mordheim and a player of Games workshops other games (Warhammer, W40k ect.) I find this game is a true homage to one of it's first true tabletop experiences, without (Well mostly) the obsessive power creeping that has come from it's latest instalments of tabletop games

Setting

Mordheim, as the name is stated, is played in the once great imperial city which is now just empty corridors and frigtening manisfestations of chaotic energy. And Mordheim the video game doesn't dissapoint. The city itself is well presented and offers the true tabletop experience, baring a few things that tabletop players are farmiliar with such as a birds eye view of the battlefield and no fog of War.

In a way this makes the game feel more like a discovering city fight than the all omnipotence view we as tabletop players come to expect, that is there are no way of knowing where your oponent is unless you take the energy to find them. I was genuenly surprised when my character walked out of a door to suddenly come face to face with a Rat Ogre. Boy did that make me a bit paranoid for open doorways and back alleys.

Overall The setting is what you would expect from this game, it hits the spot with not only a pinpoint nail, but also the flying hammer behind it.

Gameplay

Let it be known that the games i enjoy all have one thing in common, and that is not how pretty or how vibrant the world is, I am not a gamer who thinks of such trivial things so zealosly. Instead i find that the games i enjoy all have mechanics that are both easy to pick up and hard to master.

Mordheim is no different, it's mechanics very farmiliar to my knowledge of the tabletop game, with a few good exceptions. The Combat sequences do feel like they have that tabletop feel to them (Such as the no guarantee of doing a stance such as dodge or Parry), this is a good thing. It shows that the developers reseached their source material well.

However I did notice other things in game which vary way differently than their tabletop Counterpart. These features were noticeably different and feel more on the side of a computer game than a tabletop. And result in things that are rather alienating compared to it's tabletop counterpart (Which is a suggestion of you shouldn't believe everything that is being portraiyed in this game as it's tabletop counterpart) other than the few things that felt like they didn't feel right I had no quams with the system as it was hitting pretty close to home

Extra Features

Mordheim doesn't really feel like mordheim until you add the one core component from it's tabletop edition into the game, if it didn't have this it would just feel like a city fight of Warhammer Fantasy, and i would say as a person who has playedc both, they are SOO not the same

Instead the introduction of the persistant warbands and the campaign system trully make this a very well made recreation of the tabletop game and make every fight and every warband that much more investing to the player. It's not a simple matter of making a dream warband and proceeding to curb stomp every opponent out there but rather seeing your characters become the warriors they are from every bloody battle you encounter. You as a player pour your time and effort to make your characters an extension of yourself, which makes it all the more harder when those same characters lose vital parts of themselves or even perish from your roster permanently.

Mordheim the tabletop game was unforgiving to it's players and made them that much more invested in the survival or their warband, Mordheim the PC game delivers the same hit, time after time.

Verdict

Overall, I feel  that this game is truly a great extension of it's tabletop counterpart and it makes due of it's promise to give you that genuine tabletop experience. If you are a veteran of the tabletop game i would highly invest in this. For those who haven't played a tabletop game i would suggest you try this out. The concepts and mechanics can help you get through the trial stages of learning this remarkable and addictive game.

9/10

reviewText:
I really want to love this game, but I just can't in good conscious recommend it to anyone. There are too many issues.

In case you aren't aware, Mordheim is based on a skirmish tabletop by Games Workshop, though as I understand it it doesn't use the original game's rules. The adaption is a turn based strategy game in a really dark fantasy setting where you build and manage a warband. You recruit heroes and henchmen and slowly build them up by surviving randomly generated missions. There are permanent consequences anywhere, from permanent injuries after dying to downright permadeath. There is a constant race against time too since you need to deliver a ressource in time that you can gather during missions every few ingame weeks. If you manage to do it the timer is reset, but if you don't the whole game is lost. Losing too many people permanently and not being able to go to missions to gather the ressource does in essence also lose you the game permanently. This doesn't happen after 3 or 4 hours by the way, this will become a problem after 20 or 30 hours.

It would all be fine if it would all be down to your skill as a player, but there is a TON of reliance on RNG in this game. If facing permanent debilitations because of things completely outside your control is something that bothers you, dear god stay away from this game.

But it wasn't what made me quit playing ultimately (no I didn't ragequit after losing the game). What kills it is the slowness. There is a ton of waiting for enemy actions during missions and slow animations that can't be skipped or sped up. Also, the story missions are absolutely terribly designed. They are on maps that are confusing as heck with totally unclear mission directions. And they take forever. The first try you are almost guaranteed to lose until you figure out what the mission is even about. They are just a complete drag and no fun at all. After 20 hours of building my warband, seeing the forth mission of the sisterhood and thinking that I will have to face more of that ♥♥♥♥ after 20 more hours I just lost all energy and motivation.

Thanks but no thanks, there are games that are simply more fun than this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I am going to try and be as informative as I possibly can with this game.
The game has four factions each one with unique units that can wield and use varieties of armor and weapons. To start the game you are going to choose one of four factions, the choice of faction is crucial to your play style. Once chosen you are going to begin leveling, and yes you level everything, even the poor little meat shields you hide your damage dealers behind. This entire game is based on leveling, accept that fact and youll be perfectly happy with the game. Now the key detail of this game in my eyes is going to be resource management in the warband screen. EVERY MEMBER of your warband must be paid, and you must send wyrdstone to those who request it, miss four shipments and its game over. Inside your camp you can almost fully customize your characters (this is a detail of the game that i want more improvement on) by changing the styles of their gear and equipping them new armor and weapons, also training them over days in spell casting and skill use.
now once outside of your warbands camp youll be placed on the campaign screen (the newest update added this finally!). Once on the screen youll be given a variety of missions to choose from, all with varying difficulty and loot. Once you get your warband high enough you will be given an end of act mission. These end of act missions have objectives that must be completed such as placing sanctified hammers on statues, and cleansing the corruption from holy artifacts.

The actual gameplay is a turn based strategy format. Units take turns based on their initiation, this is lowered by heavier cumberson items and armor/weapons. In many ways I have found that the weaker glass cannon units go first most of the time, and depending on your faction you may or may not have any of those. Now one thing this games combat does very well is its implication of stances. there are many stances in this game including ambush dodge and parry, being the primary stances. Combat can be very difficult at times because your units move spaces may not get you in a proper postion to attack, and often leads to bottlenecking through doorways or over bridges. Each mission you recieve has a primary objective of killing all enemies or causing them to retreat. Retreat is caused by you forcibly removing morale from an enemy by either surrounding them and causing fear, or the killing of their units. (im not sure about this but it seems like killing enemy heroes and leaders causes a deeper impact on morale)
One thing to be wary of is any kind of % chance, as this game is still in Alpha I will go back and change this review as needed but as of now a 78% chance of climbing over a wall seems to have only a 30% success rate, and yes I have tested this by losing over 3 units to trying to climb one wall.

All in all this game is amazing, definitely a must have for any warhammer player, and a must try for any strategy enthusiast, this game will punish you through crippling soldiers or even permanent death though. So if you do decide to try it watch for ambushes, and stay away from charging Daemons! Enjoy!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far its good, I played this game when it first came out, and was not impressed, no custominzation, no level progres, and unless you chose the upgraded version of your class, you were going to lose alot. I am happy to report that they fixed that, each warband you make feels unique, and you star with a rookie, or later on with the right amount of coin you can be a trained rookie. So what is  the good and the bad?
Cons:
The AI can be a bit wonky, as in if another is blocking the path to get through, they will just end there turn, did have one funny moment when an ranged AI decided to jump of a 15ft wall, take fall damage and attempted to shoot and miss, felt bad for him.

The daughters of Sigmar feel a little op, if you are brand new to this game, this is the faction to avoid in combat, they are the tank/mage group, meaning they can cause lots of damage and take it, now they are fun to use and also I do appreciate they are not visually clad in bikini's as most games I see will do with an all female faction.
The Price is a little high in my opion, I bought this when I had more money, for an Early Access I understand they need every cent to make the game good, but you risk scaring people away. In this regard I would say  if a friend bought this, ask to try this game, cause if its not for you, then you will probably come to hate this game.

This game has its own lore, but if you are not a Warhammer, fantasy or 40k fan, you may be lost, I would see the Warhammer wiki page, but this is a grim dark fantasy game, meaning its not going to have a happy ending on most days. The story for now is ok, I do enjoy making my own adventure, but there is no cutscenes, (so far), so you dont see a major progresion, they are realeasing Act's as time goes on, so maybe there will be chages.

Pros:

Its a good warhammer game, visually all the characters are right, the weapons they use is correct, and all the maps feel like you are an a chaos corrupted hell hole.

Its fun to see your warband progress over time, and customize them, give them new armor, weapons, skills, so its like xcom except warhammer, and you feel the weight of their deaths.

The mission types are fun, for now, mostly its about collecting wyrdstones, and fighting enemy warbands, and if the mission is to hard you can send scouts to find different missions.

The engine is not to bad, the game visually is good, gruff, abomination look is what I would expect from a warhammer game. I hope they do add in a faction like Orks/goblins, since all the other factions have a specific reason for being there, it would be a game changer if one was there just to kill everyone, not for chaos or the empire, just for fun.

So all in all my fun rating is a 10/10, I love playng this game, but my more professional side says a 7-8/10 it has issues, some parts of the game will feel a bit unfair, like if you have a 95% chance to hit but miss 3 times, and have a dodge of 80% but get hit twice does feel a bit cheap, and if the decrease the price a bit, I would reconmend this game to all my warhammer friends. I did not play the boardgame version of Mordheim but this game has caught my interest. That feeling of conquest is always great and this review may change when its complete, but for now I reconmend this game because for the time being, even though I went into more details about the bad, its still a fun game I just went more into it because I feel that part is for the devs or people who want to see what may turn them away from this game, and weigh it in their own minds, because this is still a a fun game  and I enjoyed it.

reviewText:
EARLY ACCESS REVIEVED FIRSTLY ON 20th OCTOBER 2015. (Update 8, Patch 4, EA rating - 95/100)

This is an updated review after full-release. Changes are written with capital letters. (Release 19/NOV/2015, v. 1.0.4.1).

My overall rating for Mordheim: City of the Damned: 100/100

Another adaptation from Warhammer universe, this combines elements of real-time strategy and RPG genre. Decent atmospheric settings full of horror and merciless battles, that is what this game promises you. Add a management of your warband, improvement of skills and a decent portion of strategy with luck and you have, what it is really called. War over cursed city, which we will look into further in details.

GAMEPLAY

+ Good design and performance
+ Strategic map
+ Variety of actions and reactions (most of them are responsive)
+ Good tutorials
+ Warband management
+ Commented objectives, stories before and after the mission
+ VOICED STORIES AND INTRO ADDED
o Complex control
- Four factions only (may not be negative at all)

Gameplay is a decent part of the game and it is very well balanced. Now there are only four factions, but tactics, randomised elements on map and also important luck factor are creating a formidable game experience. Turn-based strategy is very well combined with RPG genre, so you have to improve your warband, change the position and disposition of the troops, after that, you have to fight your battles on the battlefield.

Battles need another strategy guidance, you have to rely not only on your warriors, but also to environment and luck. Everything is possible in war, so also here, even the weakest unit can disable or rout the strongest enemy with the right conditions and events happened.

Commented objectives, intros and outros to the mission are adding a great impression to the atmosphere of the whole game. Player can feel himself/herself like the biggest general and strategist in the world.

VISUALS

+ Excellent graphics
+ Art style
+ Cam view
+ Wounds have influence on characters' appearance

Visually is Mordheim stunning. Perfect set of backgrounds, various part of Mordheim, nice details on units and many features have a wonderful impression on a player. Also your warriors may suffer wounds and injuries, which are visible then, so you can tell, who is a novice and who battle-toughened veteran.

SOUNDTRACK

+ Well composed
+ Theme for each faction, map
+ RELEASED AS AN EXCLUSIVE OFFER FOR ALL PLAYERS

Soundtrack adds points for Mordheim: City of the Damned, themes are adequately changing, underlining both nature of each faction and sinister atmosphere of cursed city of Mordheim. After full release it was added and automatically downloaded to game folder (link specified at store page).

MULTIPLAYER

+ Balanced
+ Various mods
o Seeking by rating (adjustable)

Multiplayer also provides another possibilities for your warband to perform, you can choose of plenty modes and community is fair and friendly. There is also Exhibition" mode

hoursPlayed: because loss can disrupt your precisely build warband in one unlucky mission. Though you can seek the enemy just to suit your rank

so it is compensable and you do not have to have an elite unit at all.

SUMMARY

This title is a very wonderful adaptiation of Warhammer universe

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Picked it up today and haven't stopped playing it all day. It is definitely in early release stage but by far one of the better early release games on steam. At this point it's more playable than most fully released games!

Being a big fan of the Warhammer series from everything to lore and the table top (both Warhammer fantasy and 40k) I was really excited when I first discovered this a while back. Most of the games made with Games Workshop are usually the 40k space marine type or Dawn of War. This was obviously a delight because it looked like a “real” attempt at the fantasy style instead.

I was a bit hesitant to pick it up at first mainly because of the bad wrap on early releases lately and from everything I read it was meant for a console and was still pretty rough for PC users. As I watched it though it went from “mixed reviews” to “Mostly positive” the developers were releasing some awesome new content and watching some game play on youtube it looked like it might actually become a real game instead of another early release disappointment (here's looking at you Day Z).

The game play itself is pretty solid. You have the 4 factions all of which are pretty balanced and at this point pretty simple. At this point in the game you really on have the tutorials (4 of them which really do cover all the game and take less than an hour) and skirmish. You create a map and choose the opposing faction if it's against AI or you can randomly pair with another person for some PVP. The unique thing I liked about setting up the game were the vast options for starting locations or scenarios. For example you can can do standard set up (both teams start at opposite corners) you can do Ambush (one team starts all inside a building and the opposing team is surrounding the building) Fog of War (Both teams are completely scattered across the map) and the list goes on and on. The maps even at this point are impressive and I love that they randomly generate so you hardly ever get the same map twice.

The combat is pretty simple which might be a down point for some, but personally I enjoyed I. It keeps the game play fast and allows you to focus on other strategy rather than micro managing each character during their turn. You basically have two types of points for each unit Strategy Points and Offense Points (SP and OP respectively) your SP points allow for movement and your OP allow for combat which you can see pretty decently in the game play video. Depending on the skills or spells your unit has you are allowed to cycle through your available options each turn  by hitting Q or E. This helps make the combat smooth and quick. Most of the strategy is in placement of troops and sight. Much like in the tabletop game the first few turns are setting up your units in defensible areas or in getting the enemy in line of sight. This may seem tedious for those who want action but it is incredibly fun to run around as an Ogre or Cultish Wizard looking for positions of advantage.

Outside of the match you do have the option to micro manage your troops which was also fun from a looting, leveling, and buffing standpoint. You can customize your squad with gear which can be looted from battles and eventually purchased, you can spend points and level skills, spells, or abilities, and you can enchant your weaponry (Hammer of Sigmar +5 awesomeness). This makes you invested in your war band but keep in mind this game also has perma-death so don't get super attached to your beloved hero.


Some awesome things that stand out:

The overlord view during a match that allows you to plan and scope the whole map was really a cool idea and works very well.
In game log for all actions so you can see why you missed that hit or miscast a spell.
Dark fantasy art and feel is seriously awesome as hell. They did a fricken epic job making Mordheim seem like a city of dark magic corrupted by chaos.
Lore (though limited) is all accurate and pretty intriguing. It will be appreciated by fans of the genre and at the same time new players won't be confused or lost without background.

9/10 would run around for an hour as a Skaven assassin again.

This would be an amazing game for just an RPG in the style of Fable or Kingdoms of Amalur Reckoning. Give me this city as an open world map and let me build a character and I would pay an A list game price for that.

I have to say, Early Access reviews are difficult to write due to the changing nature of the beast during production. That said, I thoroughly enjoy the game and the customization of the warbands. Each warband is different and fun to play.

I haven't yet found a match-up of warbands that is completely one sided so every game has fair play. :) If you are looking for a great turn based stratagey game with amazing potential check out Mordeheim, you wont be sorry.

reviewText:
I have a love/hate relationship with this game, but I can't bring myself to rate negatively. I will, however, be leaving a lengthy review explaining my opinions of this game.

First of all its one of the best tabletop to video game conversions I have ever played. The play mechanics are superb and feel refreshing for a turn based strategy game, aside from the RNG.

The overall look and feel of the game are excellent, it is a great blend of horror and strategy. Great graphics, awesome artwork, cool noises, amazing voice acting, and genuinely creepy.

Yes the game can be immensely challenging and unforgiving, but that is one of the best parts. Real true consequences that you will be feeling the effects of for a long while to come, so play smart, be cautious.

The downside of the game is really that the AI, although incredibly tough, is incredibly stupid. Every match is basically a Zerg rush. The AI will throw everything it has at you (aside from one guy who will wander around aimlessly) right at the start of match.

The goal of the game almost entirely revolves around collecting this precious green crack called Wryd Stone. The AI is not at all interested in doing that. Instead they will mindlessly pursue you like ravenous zombies.

If they could improve the AI, wherein they actually cared about collecting the Wyrd Stone, as the game implies they should, and used some genuine strategy instead of 'walk straight at the closest enemy and kill' strategy it currently uses then this game would be huge win.

Another sore spot is the RNG. I suggest you keep a pillow close by to bite on because you will be getting royally ♥♥♥♥ed in the ♥♥♥.

The RNG seems to purposely want to cause you to smash your computer in complete rage. I have lost numerous battles, where I overwhelmingly had the tactical advantage, simply because my team would continually miss attack after attack and take every incoming hit right on the chin till they where all decimated.

There is little to nothing you can do about the RNG except pray and pray. It completely sucks the idea of 'being the smarter tactician' right out of the game. They should add in some fail safe so you can only miss so many times in a row or something along those lines because it seems no matter how likely your odds of landing a hit are its always a 3/10 chance you will actually land the hit... especially when you really really need to land that last freakin hit!

Lastly, I absolutely love the fact this game has multiplayer support. Although it is neigh impossible to find a match unless you join a community group that host pvp tournaments. It may have been the saving grace of the entire game if not for the fact that multiplayer is not balanced at all.

Every faction in multiplayer has some super cheezy tactic or advantage that will make them OP depending on what lvl your currently fighting at.
Early on the Skaven move so far and fast they can easily swarm, poison, and kill half your team before you even get to move. Later on the Sisters will drop comet after comet, after comet, after... you guessed it more comets on your head till you have two guys remaining that they quickly surround and flog to death. Late game the Mutants if played right, will have uber mutations giving them more strength and health than anyone making them a wall of flesh and claws that will pound your face, body, and soul into the ground.

If they where to improve AI, add a more forgiving RNG (so the game is more based on tactics than luck), and tweak the multiplayer balancing this game would be absolutely amazing. For now I suggest if you like tabletop games, turn based strategy, Warhammer, or are a masochist get this game next time its on sale.

I'll be looking forward to updates... if there are any.

reviewText: So what IS this game exactly? Well it is to Blackguards what the new XCOMs are to the old ones. So it's a 3D tbs. But it's designed to be pretty hardcore from the outset and this actually works because it stops you getting too strong too soon and retains an addictive quality where you just don't want to accept defeat. In this sense, then, it actually has more in common with Blackguards than any other game I can think of. The same moments of feeling absolutely robbed by the RNG and the same crazy difficulty spikes. I can understand why some have downvoted it for this reason because it can be very frustrating and it constantly autosaves so, much like a roguelike, there's no getting around failure with scum saves. I read a few reviews where people criticise the AI but, to be perfectly honest, the fact that you are outnumbered by superior forces 99% of the time means that if the AI were any better you would always be crushed. The warbands are just about different enough to be worth multiple replays and overall it's a very rewarding experience for those who can stick with it. Arguably not worth the full £30 for various reasons but anything £20 or less and you should snap it up immediately.\n\n*edit* Oh it also has pvp but most will likely be too scared to touch it until they have played many hours in campaigns. I know I am!

reviewText:
While I used to enjoy Mordheim as a Tabletop game, I feel they have failed to adapt it to a computer game setting.

There are many positive aspects from this game: The movement system is great, the ease of use (once you read the tutorials) as well as excellent graphics, but unfortunately they have failed to realise that when you morph a tabletop game into a computer game, you need to make changes.

The biggest flaw is the fact it is too easy to lose, not through skill but unfortunate dice rolls. While in most games a defeat or setback is manageable, it is possible that a few poor rolls and suddenly your warband's leader is worthless. Some will argue skill has an effect, which it does, but skill cannot prevent you rolling too many misses regardless of how good you believe you are.

If the computer received similar injuries as you did, that were visible, then things might be different. But unfortunately it's another case where the computer doesn't have to suffer as the player does, which is why I wouldn't recommend this game.

A long time coming. Turn based strategy with a perspective that makes every pawn the most important member of the team. I rarely see games with such promise and I hope they do not mess up the rest.
Pros-
+Amazing settings
+Multiple options for mobility using rules adhering to the spirit of these games
+No godly view (unlike the strategy game) Trust me this is a good thing makes the encounters and strategy dependent on predicting the other players tendencies and tactics.
+Great beginning factions who doesn't love humans? and who doesn't love stab stabbing man-thing's with a poisoned dagger?!
+Good combat rules and useful abilities that do not necessarily adhere to the original Mordheim tabletop, but deeper in the vein of what a company could do if it doesnt Cow-Tau ( :) ) to the general masses (this was never mainstream or else it would have many more fans.....)
Cons (at current writing I will edit later bro, don't taze me)
-No ability to customize units
-No long term development of units and or negative status' due to failure (Original game if you lose your team doesnt die entirely, they limp of the batlefield tend to their shattered hips and skewered eyes and suffer consequences for next battle, eg. your archer gets killed and he ends up with a shattered eye socket.... sorry bro might as well retire at that point)
-Random Maps aren't really random (just goes through existing maps)
-no map setup like in the original game (plecement of pieces obstacles and traps, with traps being able to be randomly generated based on terrain added would be a nice touch. ;) )
- constant camera swapping back to one character (Good view swap system but lets keep that F-r static k?)

Overall:
Great franchise with great promise, I bought four copies for my diehard friends and will buy one for my friend in O'Canadia if he ever gets in touch ;)
I hope they develop this into a great game and I sincerely look forward to what else they can do to make this turn-based strategy better than the rest.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In 1999 I was 14 and very much an impressionable nerd. My friends were interested in Warhammer Fantasy and one of them got the 3rd Edition 40k starter box. I had a look at his White Dwarf magazines and Mordheim jumped out to me. A role playing games based on end-time conspiracy theory set in the WHFB universe. Of course in 1999 we had the whole year 2000 prophesy nuts going beserk.

My first warband was the Cult of the Possessed, followed by the Witch Hunters. My friends played Skaven, Undead and Orcs, the last of which was released in White Dwarf magazine. My friend who played Skaven let his brother use the mercs from the starter box, and my own brother got the starter box and used mercs as well. On top of this, the table-top club we went to had about half a dozen guys also buy the starter box. In up, we had at least 12 people playing all different warbands every weekend for about 3 years.

Around 2003, I moved away from my home town and stopped table-top gaming for a while. I picked it up again however in 2009 and started playing Mordheim again until 2011. Life was a lot faster and I couldn't play as much as I used to. When I heard about this game coming out, I immediately jumped on board the band wagon because of my teenage passion for it and rekindling the fires of my youth.

Now for the game itself.

I feel that the game could use a little spit and polish to improve a few graphical and sound issues (as well as some dodgy camera angles), but overall this game captures the feeling of playing the tabletop game. The music and visuals are incredibly atmospheric and the turn based nature of the game works well as a translation of the table-top to the PC. Would I change any gameplay elements? Not really. The only real thing i'd like to see added is the ability to play a multiplayer campaign against friends or with jump-in games to mix things up a little bit.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just writing this as a fan/player of the old boardgame and of this early access. I've been in the EA for almost a year now. To start out it was very bare bones and glitchy, kinda what I expected.

The constant updates are perfect. They iron out all the problems that I've noted/reported.

The game looks great (graphically it's not the best, not the worst) thematically. They nailed the atmosphere of the boardgame/lore!

Now with the addition of the continous campaign/warband!? This is the game I've been dying for!!! I absolutely love the advancement and the customization options. Not to mention the fact that I can take my exhisting band and throw it online against another person and keep all the loot/xp for my single player campaign (and vise versa) not to mention the possibility of losing one of my leaders/followers for good! It's the perfect platform for the RPG and TBS fan!

I'm really enjoying this game now, and with the addition of the campaign I recommend it to anyone whos a fan of tactical turn based and roleplaying games!!! Can't wait to see where they'll go next!

reviewText:
Update -

I'm having more fun then before.  I've found more bugs and the story missions can be confusing sometimes.  But, the epic feel of survival is great.  I'm not one to complain that I miss a 95% roll.  I don't believe that game is broke or cheats, I believe I just had a bad roll.  I also hit the other day when I had a 7% chance on a shot.  It is random and it happens, but games like this are built that way.  I don't want to know exactly what is going to happen every sword swing that would be pretty dumb.

The injuries don't bother me.  I don't ever deploy my own troops, I always let the computer deploy them for me.  I like the difficulty.  I have a Human Merc warband and we've struggled and also dominated.  Nothing better then getting smacked around, scrapping together after the fight and going out and deciminating your enemy next time.  Yes you can do that.

This game is simply fantastic.  There are minor issues here and there and some odd graphic glitches.  But, overall the game requires thought and planning.  But, I think it captures the warhammer world very well and handles the mechanics of the boardgame.

I wish it had multiplayer servers and warbands were stored online for online play.  Some kind of ladder or online campaign would be great as well.

I would buy additional warbands as DLC.  I would also pay for multiplayer.  It is a great merc sim and really has been the kind of game I've been waiting for.

Well done, Well done indeed.

9.0 out of 10.  Would like multiplayer ladders, servers, clans etc...  Also multiplayer campaigns.  I hope this is game is a hit and they look at funding or kickstarting some of those features.  We also need more custom options for faces.  All my guys look the same and that is annoying.  Make it so people can mod.

reviewText:
Very promising and reminds a lot of the old cult classic tabletop game. So far only 2 warbands, Skaven and human mercenaries, but they will add a lot more over time. Mechanics are fun, graphics and sounds are good. Overall a fun turnbased experience with a very interesting new take on action points, and how they work.

Update: With the full release here and 4 warbands instead of two. They added Sisters of Sigmar, a hard-hitting band of religious nutcases Warhammer style as well as adding Cult of the Possessed, which is a Chaos warband, with all that that brings. Mutations, weird way of thinking and just plain barbarism.

With over 100 hours logged, I have this to say: The game is very unforgiving, and at times extremely frustrating. Very long load times, which seems to be something the company can't fix because of how the game is built. it has a built in anti-rage quitter system, meaning if you quit during any mission or skirmish, it treats it as if the warband got routed and EVERY SINGLE WARRIOR in the fight will have to roll on the injury table to see if they suffer any injury or lose any equipment. This is very harsh, especially for single player where you don't really hurt anyone by abandoning a mission that goes really, really bad (considering the loss of one skilled warrior can set you back around 10 hours of game time). it doesn't help the AI is dumb as bricks, and pathfinding for large units really is an issue. More than once, I see them stuck by a door and just can't move.

Still, even with its flaws this game is very addictive and I stand by my early access opinion, the game is great.

reviewText:
Fun game,  going to go with a thumbs up.  Will get into the biggest downfall of this game in 'cons'  Let me say that I never played this specific 'board' game but am a fan of board games in general.

Pros:
-Good graphics and runs seemlessly on a high end machine
-Good tactical action/squad based combat
-Development of your mercanary warband including leveling them up and equiping
-Random/procedurely generated ruined city scapes.  There is also a story line as well but this game isnt story driven.
-Just an overall fun game imho.  If you are into fantasy-esque, squad turn based tactical combat this game is worth checking out.

Cons:
-This game is hard.  Frustratingly hard.  Its not hard because of ingenous AI.  This games main issue is the fact that the RNG acts strangely.  It appears to be broken -or- coded by the devs for you to intentionally fail.  I tend to think its the 2nd of the two.  Now this isnt always a bad thing BUT be prepared to miss 5 attacks with a 70% chance to hit BUT only when you REALLY need to hit.  For me this isnt a deal breaker, Im kind of a masochist I guess.

Overall a fun game, I would definately recommend it if you can deal well with failure (because you WILL fail).

Skaven suck!

reviewText:
I really enjoy the art style and concept  of this game, but it has a few kinks that need working out.  The AI is really lackluster, and generally he hardest enemies to fight get caught on obstacles due to poor pathing, which makes for anticlimactic games in general. I haven't tried my hand in multiplayer yet, mostly because no one ever seems to be on, and I'm not going to wait around for half an hour in matchmaking to play a game. The Ui is a bit clunky, and could really do with some streamlining. It honestly seems like they designed the controls with consoles in mind. Having the ability to tie active skills to hotkeys would be really nice, and better skill navigation in general. Overall though, this game is really enjoyable and its very easy to get caught up in the story of your warband, and there is a lot of room for tactical depth. It is like a renaissance xcom with more options. I would recommend this game if you have time to burn and like turn based strategy in small unit engagements.


8/10

A genius conversion of tabletop game Mordheim. What else to say. for GW outsider.... X-COM, man, with wyrdstone harvesting - if you love it, buy this without hesitation. - Unlimited enemy reinforcements in story misions. If you loose some precious turns, you will get swarmed (especially if your party is not proper prepared)

9/10  I claim to be affected by my love to warhammer world so deduct at least two point if you are not :)

reviewText:
Mordheim: City of the Damned is an infuriating, venom-dripping, and chaotic experience. However, it is an altogether pleasant experience and game. Mordheim: CotD is a turn-based video game adapation of the tabletop Mordheim game set in the Warhammer Fantasy universe, where the goal is to survive a hellish landscape in order to gather a rare, and dangerous, material known as Wyrdstone, known for its chaotic influence and ability to enhance magic. Being set in the more turbulent era of Warhammer Fantasy history, there is an abundance of weapons to use that are unique, magic with consequences, strict limitations and possible firing zones with ranged weapons (of which there are bows and firearms), and mythical races of characters. While this game does not have all of the races from the older Mordheim, the four chosen are very different and give a very accurate (read: grimdark) feel for the setting.

The four races in CotD are the Empire Mercenaries, Skaven, Cult of the Possessed, and the Sisters of Sigmar. These races are divided into Warbands, consisting of (as time goes on) one Leader unit, up to three Hero units, one Impressive unit, and five Henchmen units. Following will be a generalization of each race, their purpose, and then a general playstyle (though this game is nearly limitless with how you create your Warband, and how you play them, especially with injuries being added into the mix). Spoilers will be placed for storyline, although only very vague information is given.
The Empire Mercenaries are a warband of human mercenaries from the proud coalition of human factions.
The Empire Mercenaries are part of the Order alignment, implying good intentions and care for the world.
The mercenaries are sent to gather Wyrdstone for their employer. They do not care about his reasons.
Mercenaries generally rely on tankier melee units and higher damage ranged units. Amazing in a team, this warband has issues if separated, for a ranged character is helpless if ambushed in melee, and will die from a few hits, while a melee character lacks the damage to best his opponent, leaving them locked in combat for several turns.The Skaven are a race of greedy and cruel humanoid rat-men, particularly from Clan Eshin, a clan of assassins.
The Skaven are part of the Chaos alignment, working for selfish intentions and care little for anybody but themselves.
The Skaven warband is attempting to gather Wyrdstone, which they call Warpstone, in order to increase personal prestige among the ranks of the influential Murderlord.
The Skaven are low health with high Initiative (order of who goes first per turn) and high damage. They generally rely on quickly swarming an enemy (one of their racial skills, appropriately named Swarm, gives bonuses for every Skaven attacking the same unit) and wiping them out one or two at a time. Lacking any tanks until they get their Impressive rank warrior, they rely on Dodging and Parrying even more than the other races. The Cult of the Possessed are a faction of mutants and chaos warriors with no regard for life at all.
The Cult is a Chaos-aligned faction, willing to murder and betray, and even mutate their own bodies, for more power.
The Cult is attempting to obtain greater and greater power from an entity known as the Shadowlord, in exchange for Wyrdstone.
The Cult is generally a more melee oriented unit, though they have a Magician as their Leader, and rely on overwhelming power to kill their foes. Lots of buffs, decent health, and high damage make them a force to be reckoned with, especially in the scarily narrow streets of Mordheim.The Sisters of Sigmar are a zealous group of religious fanatics, similar to Paladins from other games.
The SoS are aligned with Order, hoping to combat evil and to spread the message of their god through face-smashing.
The SoS are attempting to gather all of the Wyrdstone simply so that it cannot fall into the hands of evil.
The SoS generally rely on powerful and high health units to completely destroy their enemies in combat. However they are slow, and have a very difficult time dealing with multi-level attacks.
Mordheim is a very dangerous place often causing injuries to your Warband ranging from a simple experience loss, to amputation, and death. The game is very unforgiving, and you may make two or three Warbands, having them be crippled and ruined one after the other, until something finally clicks and you surge ahead, destroying your opposition and doing SO good until your main warrior loses an arm, and can no longer use that bow/halberd/shield that you relied on, and you scream into the night, causing dogs to bark, and you fume and pace around your room trying to decide if you should get a new Leader, make a new Warband, or accept the 20% dodge increase from losing an arm, and you just keep rambling and crying and pout... sorry, that hit a little close to home. As a game of incredibly high risk though, the RNG is downright out to get you, and you will often miss attacks you had an 85% chance to hit. Twice. This may seem unfair, however it is more accurately tied to the tabletop game where you'd roll upwards of five die per attack. Yet, even with an AI you swear is cheating, your best warrior being taken down by a stupid ambush that you totally weren't in range of, and RNG causing you to lose your best tank because he missed a 97% parry chance, victory is insanely addicting.

Mordheim: CotD, despite being brutal and unfair, is one of the few games I've played in a long time that really made my victories feel hard-fought and well-earned. I'm addicted to finding out what I could do, and could have done, better. 8/10
TL;DR: Hard game, lots of customization, game literally hates you, you may want to amputate your own limbs (I mean, hey, 20% bonus dodge chance!). Awesome.

reviewText:
I was on the fence, wether to recommend this game or not. Something between Walkyria Chronicles and XCOM, in a dark fantasy setting. If you love the setting, that should be a no-brainer I think. For others... I just don't know.
Than again, it may be about 6/10 for me score wise,but I wouldn't just say to stay out of it.
It is, in fact, a good game, but with a ton of things that irritate me.

First of all, the game is hard. Which is not a bad thing in itself. First time I ran the game, did the first tutorial,
fully customized my first warband and... I died almost instantly.
So I read some tips in the Internet and also armed with my previous experience... I created a new warband and never lost yet. The game has an AI that you can exploit easily. In fact, just playing it slow and carefully is enough for the AI to not know how to tackle you. It promotes slow movements and usage of the choke points. Anything else is just inviting the punishment it seems (though If someone says I'm not doing it right, I won't object, maybe I didn't figure out other tactics).
After that, it eventually gets repetetive. Shipments feel much more of a chore than fun, but it seems that they are the one thing that forces you to try and explore the map in search of resources.
On top of all of that, the game is slow. Yes, it is a turn based game, but it is not slow because you have to think much, it is slow because you click end of turn and wat... And you wait more than you play. And you wait while it loads. It might be not fair to judge the game based on such a thing like this, but in the end - it affects the satisfaction you get from the game.
Visually... There are not many models to choose from. There are plenty of color skins though, so I am on the fence here. It's ok, but it could have been much better. I think that customization and sticking to your characters with their backstories is the huge strength of the game.
I see the potential in this game. It could as well turn 6 to 8 out of 10 if it is going to be worked upon. Otherwise, hard to say.

reviewText:
A solid game, it’s hard to get going on this one but once you build up your war band it gets a little easier. This game makes you want to look after your warriors due to the perma death/injury system every decision you make counts. After 60 hours of game play I can say I would defiantly recommend this game to fans of the warhammer universe.

RNG is a huge part of this game I would be lying if I said it did not matter how lucky you are, you will find times when you are about it attack an enemy and all you will be thinking is please hit! Please hit! and…… Swing and a miss! But that’s the game if you can deal with stuff like that you will have a blast.

Anyone who knows what this game is about or even reads up on it should know what they are letting themselves in for it is not a friendly game, but by god once you get into it you don’t want to let go.

I play Skaven it was hard going at first but I love my little warband now, you can even customize the colouring of the armour I mainly use it so I know where my hero’s and leaders are, the weapon rarity and choice leave a little bit to be desired having only 3 tiers of weapon quality. Its fine but I could think of better ways to do it. (not going to go into it in a review) the stats system works well and is easy to understand, the single player campaign is all I have played since release and I can say it works well and is very fun the campaign missions are nice and add a lot more depth into the game.

The voice actor for the Skaven campaign did a great job, I have not played multiplayer since the release but I did play it during early access, it is just as fun as the single player IMO, a little harder depending on your opponent.
8.5/10 from me for this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a lot of potential, but as a very early access title it's lacking a *lot* of content at the moment. The base combat system is easy enough to grasp (though the keyboard controls feel clunky at times) yet still hints at a lot of depth in gameplay. I'm really looking forward to seeing what they do with the single player campaign/warband progression.
The game captures the world and atmosphere of Warhammer Fantasy quite well with good character and level models/textures. I did notice that a failed climb-down animation using a Sister parted her torso from her legs a bit and exposed the nothingness inside, but it's early access and that's only a small visual bug.
The only gameplay bug I encountered was on the Temple of Sigmar map, skirmishing against AI and playing as the defender in the siege scenario. It took me a few turns to realise what was happening as I had no idea where the AI team was - they were trapped outside and didn't seem capable of getting in (which I think required climbing) so it would have been up to the defender to exit and engage the enemy.

Given the newness I have no idea how good (or bad) the company is at updating and sticking to schedule etc., so can't comment on that yet. Looking forward to playing more as the updates come. The game is definitely worth keeping an eye on even if you're not interested in playing the early access (which I usually avoid, but I'm a fan of WHFB so I couldn't wait for this).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey guys and gals this will be my second review ever.

Mordheim:City of the Damned.

what can i say about it? well until recently i woudl say it was a good single player skirmish game against an AI opponent...

as i said Until recently.

Recently there has been an update that saw to a little bug that would cause the game to go into ( cue ominous movie trailer voice )INFINITE LOADING SCREEN. this had cause many people to avoid the online portion as fear of being stuck thinking it was loading.

Now with the recent update it would appear that the bug has been seen to...but then again im only going off of 1 online match so far... >.>;;

As of RIGHT now there are only 2 warbands available while you can fight against 2 other in the tutorials you cannot access them as playable or contestable AI.

The 2 warbands are the Humans and the RatMan race known as the Skaven.

These two warbands are rather entertaining in the EA build but i do feel some of the fun in making a warband isn't there because as of right now it is premade warbands.( this is just for E/A) ( i also hope that the types of units will be expanded upon later hopefully AR (After Release) if not the ability to buy specific units ( which will Definitely be added later on in the E/A) might make for interesting play.

The city of Mordheim is a Dark Fantasy Locale. When I say dark i mean DARK.  im nor one hundred percent sure if it's implemented but when i have tried to use a daylight setting in my games it still feels like night ( i think it may have to do with the everlasting storm over Mordheim )

there are some camera issues which are being adressed by the dev team. these issues, at least for me, mainly consist of the view going behind a wall and not being able to see your attacks.

these are minro things that are being adressed.

now you may ask then why bring them up? because i wanted to shwo you how in touch with the community this dev team is.

lets get down to it then for you TL;DR people

Pros

+Setting and atmosphere
+ sound
+ fun gameplay
+ fun features to be executed at a later date
+ Dev team that is in touch with the community

cons

-Atmosphere can seem kind of stale ( when day and night don't appear, to me anyways, to be any different)
-camera issues at current stage of E/A
- E/A so not all features are available

Suggestion for you

If you wish to be part of a community that is iving feedback to the dev team and having their voices heard buy the game now

if you do not wish to have the E/A version hold off for a few months until it is farther along and purchase then..

final suggestion...

Purchase. this. game.

Here is a list of reasons:
Please note, I do enjoy this game, but with the current price it just isn't worth it. If you really want it, wait for a sale. Please note that this game is till being updated, so in the future you could buy it, after bug fixes and the game is more nicely ironed out. (Also note that this review may quickly become outdated. The game can be quite glitchy, for instance, one time one of my warriors randomly fell through a floor (Which by the way should not happen) and was stuck underneath a building for the entire game. There are many other glitches as well.

The game is quite unbalanced, the skaven, for instance, are very unbalanced, instead of adapting the board games way of balancing it they decided to change it. See, the skaven in the board game are very weak and dull, but they come in great numbers. In the game however, they are very strong and almost impossible to hit. They have little health, but hit stronger than the sisters of sigmar, and your lucky to hit them.

Oh yeah, and the game is based entirely on chance.

I also feel that some of the impressives should be stronger, specifically the Sisters of Sigmars impressive. She's pathetic. I got into a map and I saw a skaven players rat ogre. So, I charged her at it because it was exposed and there were no skaven near by. Then she missed all of her attacks, and was killed in two turns by the rat ogre with help from another skaven who ran across the entire map, because, oh right, the skaven are also incredibly fast.

If you want to win multiplayer battles, just play as the skaven!

Just to clarify, I like this game, but it should still be in early access. This game is just so broken and needs lots of fixes and patches. The price tag is ridiculous considering how broken this game is, if it were in early access it could be excused. But I can't let this game escape from my talons. So I will say again, FIX THE GAME. reviewText:
Call this more for a first impressions review as I played 10-15 missions.

Negatives:
Game needs more storyline added to it.
Needs more races to fight against.
Needs more race (warband) choices for players to play.
Graphics or okish.
Tutorial depth is very much needed as info provided lacks.
More options for appearance needs to be added.
Needs different style of maps included.  Feels relatively the same running between 2-3 maps.  Maps are randomized terrain settings, but still feel the same.
Needs more weapon options.
Could use more scenarios!

Positives:
Turn based.  I do like turn based games more than most other styles.
Relatively easy to navigate when upgrading/building your warband.  Only takes a little bit of looking and fumbling about to figure or remember it.
I do like the idea of randomized terrain, but not at the expense of less maps in which to do it on.


Overall, this game should have stayed in beta until they added depth to it.  As it stands right now, there isn't much for appearance options, races, missions, storyline, and maps in which you fight on.

Haven't really tried out the pvp as the visual on the game and the options that are available don't seem very appealing or varied enough to make anything unique to your warband.  So i didn't bother with it.

At best, for me, it is a game I will or may play every once in a great while.  I mostly play storyline games so I can be partially biased. However, such games as Blood Bowl I do play because of the pvp aspect. Might have to try pvp out and hope the matchmaking doesn't take long.

As of right now though, there just isn't enough in this game to keep and hold my interest for long with a lack of...well...everything I guess.

reviewText:
I have enjoyed this game since early access so to me this game has only gotten better but i'll break it down into positive / negative things there are to look out for so you can decide on your own if you would consider the same things positive / negative.

Negative:

- Still has some optimization to do

- There is a chance you will find an invisible wall or an invisible wall will be created because of something in the map

- Has a relatively high learning curve if you have not played anything like this before which can be overwhelming and may need to be taken in more than 1 session.

- Has no multiplayer unless you find a friend to set it up with or get very lucky some random person around your warbands lvl is looking for a game.

- A total of 4 races -> humans, Chaos, Skaven and Sisters of sigmar is a big issue for some even though i once again am fine with this number since i don't jump between races a lot.

- Most common complaint i can think of is the variation in missions (all missions are optional. Main objective is always to beat the opponents warband or make them rout before you lose or rout)

-> Wyrdstone Rush where you collect typically 45% - 60% of the wyrdstone in the map to complete the OPTIONAL      objective

-> Marked for death where you have certain targets from the other warband normally between 1 and 3 specific people you need to kill and take an insigna from

-> Crush their will where you are tasked with retrieving the opponents idol and bring it back to your own cart

I completely understand why some people would consider this a too small amount of missions even though i am completely fine with them.


Positive:

- They have done a great job at making your warband feel like they matter giving you that classic fear of someone getting killed or sustaining a permanent injure like an arm or a leg that has been severed.

- The insane number of different abilities both passive and active you can gain through the lvl up system

- The ability to equip your mercenaries with different weapons and armor to suit your playstyle not to mention the rarity difference from common to epic quality

- The depth they have put into the lvling. You are able to lvl up your warband, your mercenaries and give them stat ups, the different wyrdstone collecters and you can in a way lvl up the game with their veteran system.
Some of these make very little difference but make a nice surprise sometimes while others will be looked at as a goal to obtain after 1 - 2 missions


Summary:

I think the game has things to work on and i completely understand some of the concerns some might have but the most importent thing to me is the fact that the game runs well and provides a lot of things to do when you are not on a mission and a great tactical experience when you are in a mission.

It is very easy to look at the game at first and think of it as unforgiving and very hard but once you get the hang of it the game becomes very interesting and i will absolutely recommend this game.

reviewText:
Possibly the greatest existing example of game developers hiding a unfinished, poorly executed game onto the market. The AI in this game does odd moves, ignores objectives, stares at walls, yet will B Line to your weakest guy and try and swarm him with no regard for the battle. It does this to simply inflict permanent damage on your warband, while its crew are just randoms that are totaly expendable. The Overwatch melee stance works sometimes, other times enemy stroll past without a care, only to somehow stun their target with a damn knife ?  You will never get a charge off on an overwatched enemy, the tiny split second between the charge option showing and the enemy counter charging you is about half a second.
The skill tree in this game costs so much yet delivers mostly marginal effects, maybe a %5 increase onto an ability. Only to see your investment wasted when your guy ends up with a headwound that turns him into a potato. Replacement guys are vastly overpriced for a measly 1 or 2 level character, and because they are the weakest , will be targeted by the AI and go down faster then a crack ♥♥♥♥♥ . There are hardly any decent items found as loot, or for sale, so dont count on outfitting a new guy to the max.
Yet this games most offensive, and just plain insulting aspect is its totaly broken and deceptive Random Number Generator. Stare in disbelief as attack after attack at %95 misses (not parried or dodged). Gaze in awe as the AI lands powershot after powershot on your warbands leader who had a %80 dodge enabled. From what I have observed in 300 hours of game on several accounts, the AI gets a %25 bonus and you get a %25 penalty.
So go through mission after mission of danger, builld your followers up, only to watch them die . There is no end point to this game,it just grinds you down. Win 100 battles yet in 1 bad battle where the AI pulls ♥♥♥♥ from its ♥♥♥♥ and stuns on near every hit, and your main guys end up with game ending wounds.
Wish a decent company had worked on this game, instead of this pile of ♥♥♥♥ brick muppets. They know exactly the problems but cant be ♥♥♥♥ed fixing it.

reviewText:
I think I would enjoy this game a great deal more if it was even minutely less 'hardcore.'  Such as allowing saved game files after completed missions, and reloading to those saves after those successful missions.  Or, I don't know, maybe a way to remove the permanent, random, and absolutely brutal injury penalties units receive faster than most people can blink.

Being a completionist, I find many of the game mechanics infuriating, not least of which is the steep learning curve with ZERO forgiveness for accidents, mistakes, and inattention.  I play games to relax, and this game.  It is not relaxing.

If, however, you like the Fantasy Warhammer setting, and the 'uh-murs-uv' atmosphere it actually manages to achieve, then this game is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I purchased the early access game on Halloween after reading some pretty great sounding reviews. Just a little bit of background I don't write reviews on video games EVER as I haven't found any that stand out to me enough to warrant a review (please note I'm 21 and have been gaming since I was about 6). I am a fan of strategy games such as xcom, civ 5, galactic civ, Dawn of War 1 & 2. Mordheim as an early access game has already managed to push them out of my mind. It is challenging but not ridiculously like dark souls (which is important as at that level of challenging the game is no longer fun). I find myself attached to the characters on my team and worrying way more than I should about my characters surviving.

The things I love about this game
- Warband team style play offers customization for play style ergo you can use 1 hand weapons, 2 hand weapons, archers, magic all to your play style
- 2 resources gold and wyrdstones which can make for some extra complexity as you have to ensure you have enough of both otherwise you'll tick someone off (not enough gold and you can't pay for treatments or pay your soldiers not enough wyrdstones and you won't be able to make your quota to your employer)
- Have yet to find any really overpowered units. using 1 hand weapons for example you lose damage if you compare it to a 2 hand weapon but you gain dodge chance or you can equip a shield and be able to parry.
- Magic abilities have the chance to backfire or curse characters as you use it so you can't train your mage up to be as ***kicker and use him to kill the whole enemy team (atleast from what I've seen so far).
- It's only early access which means they are actually looking at reviews and bugs and game suggestions and actually fixing them and modifying the game so it can only go up from here!

Things that I feel should be addressed
- I say addressed as it's in early access still so most of these are just things that need to be tweaked as they're still working on the game.
- the percentages for tasks appear a little skewed to me. what I mean is I'll have a 75 percent chance to hit someone I'll attack them 4 times and miss all 4 times. This get's a little irritating when you have your havy hitter who has a big 2 handed weapons that does but loads of damage but can only attack once per turn and he constantly misses. Or when you are trying to climb a wall and you have a 70 percent chance and you use all of your moves falling and injuring your character who is wearing cloth armor and is an archer (near killed him doing this).
If you ask me archers are a little underpowered making them reload was a good check and balance however they do very little damage and can only attack once per turn (keep in mind they're just hitting the first skill point for me so I may be able to upgrade them down the road to be better)

Ergo just off of the campaign to the first act this game is awesome! I haven't even touched the multiplayer yet!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At this stage of its development, I have to say I am thoroughly enjoying the game, the graphics are great and I think the city itself is quite atmospheric.  Navigation takes a little practice, but after a while any awkwardness sort of fits the twisted nature of the place.  Gameplay is good, game speed needs refining but I am sure the developers will iron things out as they continually make well thought out improvements.  Really impressed so far and am happy to have parted with my cash.  Character development is also fun - you may find that the peg leg, one eyed survivor of many a nightmarish encounter will still be in your team long after he may have wanted to retire.....

I think this is worth a blast, but be prepared to have plenty of time to complete some of the main campaign missions as no saves in game (at least that I could find) mean a long session unless you want to force your team to retreat in order to turn the computer off and get on with real life!

1. Characters will have to make all alone checks even though there are friendly characters 2 ft. away from other friendly characters.
2. stupidity checks from skull fractures completely destroys a chrarcter's usefullness. my warlock has a 14 intellegence, is lucky to pass a stupidity check 20% of the time. tone down the difficulty of the checks.
3. exiting the game causes the match to be a rout and all of your characters take injuries. ive had it where i had to exit the game because the game crashed and when i turned it back on, 3 of my guys had missing arms. i shouldnt be punished for having to turn off the game. i realize that the devs dont want players to exit the game when their warband is being beat, but there are better ways. XCOM EU had the ironman mode. the game would save whenever a action is completed. that way players couldnt just go back and redo past actions.
4. Blue items get lost on characters way too often. i beat a warband decisively and only had 1 casualty. the captain comes back without injury BUT somewhere along the lines, he lost his blue shield, sword and helmet. thats insane. blue items seem to get lost more than white items. maybe its just me overreacting, but those blue items are insanely useful when it comes to fighting stronger warbands or doing story missions. losing them with the frequency as I have can have terrible effects in the long run. i dont want there to be no chance of dropping them, just a little lower chance of it. maybe add in a perk that makes it impossible (or extremely unlikely) for them to drop a designated item?
5. Not being ablr to leap across a gap because there is a enemy 1 story below you. i dont think this was intentional. probably just a glitch.

I really REALLY like the game, but its a really frustrating game. A lot of it comes from the RNG, but thats just the nature of the game. i really hope that the devs listen to the players and tweak the game for the better.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWith the release of warband progression, this game has taken a giant leap ahead. I feel obligated to also help put down some criticisms that I've been seeing on the forums. Firstly, and perhaps most importantly, this game is a PORT OF THE ORIGINAL MORDHEIM game from tabletop fantasy warhammer. This game is made by mordheim fans FOR mordheim fans. The reason that there are bubbles around the characters is because of Movement Bases. The reason that you cannot loot everything on the map after youve won is because you couldnt loot everything on the table after youve won. If you want to do that then youll have to cripple the other warband and hope they dont route. The reason that there are only 4 warbands is because ........ you guessed it, in the original Mordheim there were only 4 warbands. Human, Sisters of Sigmar, Skaven, and Chaos. There were other warbands created by the community, but nothing official by games workshop. Ive been playing Mordheim for over 16 years off and on and I find todays gamers to be quite spoiled and childish with some of these complaints on the forums. Mordheim isnt for all the whiney little griefers, its for the die hard fans of warhammer and its franchises. Grow up steam community.

reviewText:
The new campaign mode is every thing I was hoping for! I love a tactics game that allows for random non-story line missions that can be done as often as desired! The game is challenging and you are just as likely to take a loss as you are to push through to victory! I highly recommend this game and am so looking forward to more to come!

UPDATE 11/21/15

100hrs into the game and I still love it just as much as I did at hour 1. I have already suggested this game to many of my friends. As a turn-based rpg fanatic I love the way the game plays and the unique abilities for each warband. The permanent injury system is a nice touch, if not heart breaking at times (your star hero gets swarmed by skaven and ends up losing an arm). The maps are great, have a very Mordheim feel to them and pleasing to the eye. Some suggested improvements:

*In-battle equip system. On the occasion I've accidentally sent my warband in and my warrior only has a dagger after getting robbed the last battle. After killing a rival, I can put a sword in my backpack but not simply hold it in my mainhand. I'd even be cool with the action costing strategy points to equip, etc.

*Skills are way too expensive for the amount of gold you are able to make. I literally have an entire roster of warriors with 2-4 skill points because I simply cannot afford to pay for all of them to skill up and still meet the constant demands for wyrdstone shipments. Average low skill is 95 gold (and I have the scholar veteran skill too), the higher level skills range to upwards of 280-300 gold. Even after completing a 259lb wyrdstone shipment I'm only able to pay for two or three skills before I'm in danger of not being able to pay for treatments, equipment loss, and upkeep. I suggest perhaps a separate currency system for skills? or a lowering of their price, or an increase in wyrdstone shipment payouts? Or maybe even just dropping the gold cost as you already require skill points themselves?

*Wyrdstone shipments come at regular intervals with increasing amount required and it is a great idea. It gives you a huge reason to harvest the pesky green crystals. However, the demand is a bit strenuous. It would be a lot easier to pay for skill upgrades and my warband in general if the demands weren't so constant. I love the system, but maybe a reprieve between shipments would help tremendously? Sometimes being able to send small shipments to one of the side smugglers helps out a lot, but then in doing so puts me behind the 8-ball on the next demand that comes within a day or two of the last completed.

Love the game, keep up the good work. I've got three open games going so I need to get back to my mercenaries. Look forward to updates and hopefully more warbands. (I'm looking at you Dwarves, Undead, Orks, elves (both kind), Witch Hunters, and *hopefully* lizardmen.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was enjoying my adventures through the Damned City for a while, having hired and trained up a pair of Warlocks from youth while leading a human warband, because their lightning strikes are dazzling.

It was the first time a man went down in a while, as one of the mages got downed early on in a recent encounter with Sigmar by an unlucky stun, while the other blew himself up in an unavoidable spell backfire effect known only as Tzeentch's Wrath, causing him to lose consciousness instantly, in the same encounter as the first. Although my Ogre and leader pushed back the Sisters of Sigmar, I feared I would have to gather wyrdstone without the Warlocks for a while, but they both ended up with mental scars... Megalomania, meaning they could not cast spells ever again. An unrecoverable psychological illness, they might as well have died in the service of the empire, so I sent them into an early retirement.

Making matters worse, this could be the end of my warband. With a pressing wyrdstone shipment deadline and not enough good men left to survive an encounter with the wandering demons, recovering resources to hire good men is out of the question while I muster up the courage to drag inexperienced henchmen into battle, training them up from scratch.

This story is why Mordheim has potential -- I cannot wait to lead other bands of warriors into battle, but I would like to bring a medic for long-term treatment of the most insidious afflictions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I purchased the early access game on Halloween after reading some pretty great sounding reviews. Just a little bit of background I don't write reviews on video games EVER as I haven't found any that stand out to me enough to warrant a review (please note I'm 21 and have been gaming since I was about 6). I am a fan of strategy games such as xcom, civ 5, galactic civ, Dawn of War 1 & 2. Mordheim as an early access game has already managed to push them out of my mind. It is challenging but not ridiculously like dark souls (which is important as at that level of challenging the game is no longer fun). I find myself attached to the characters on my team and worrying way more than I should about my characters surviving.

The things I love about this game
- Warband team style play offers customization for play style ergo you can use 1 hand weapons, 2 hand weapons, archers, magic all to your play style
- 2 resources gold and wyrdstones which can make for some extra complexity as you have to ensure you have enough of both otherwise you'll tick someone off (not enough gold and you can't pay for treatments or pay your soldiers not enough wyrdstones and you won't be able to make your quota to your employer)
- Have yet to find any really overpowered units. using 1 hand weapons for example you lose damage if you compare it to a 2 hand weapon but you gain dodge chance or you can equip a shield and be able to parry.
- Magic abilities have the chance to backfire or curse characters as you use it so you can't train your mage up to be as ***kicker and use him to kill the whole enemy team (atleast from what I've seen so far).
- It's only early access which means they are actually looking at reviews and bugs and game suggestions and actually fixing them and modifying the game so it can only go up from here!

Things that I feel should be addressed
- I say addressed as it's in early access still so most of these are just things that need to be tweaked as they're still working on the game.

UPDATE 11/21/15

100hrs into the game and I still love it just as much as I did at hour 1. I have already suggested this game to many of my friends. As a turn-based rpg fanatic I love the way the game plays and the unique abilities for each warband. The permanent injury system is a nice touch, if not heart breaking at times (your star hero gets swarmed by skaven and ends up losing an arm). The maps are great, have a very Mordheim feel to them and pleasing to the eye. Some suggested improvements:

*In-battle equip system. On the occasion I've accidentally sent my warband in and my warrior only has a dagger after getting robbed the last battle. After killing a rival, I can put a sword in my backpack but not simply hold it in my mainhand. I'd even be cool with the action costing strategy points to equip, etc.

*Skills are way too expensive for the amount of gold you are able to make. I literally have an entire roster of warriors with 2-4 skill points because I simply cannot afford to pay for all of them to skill up and still meet the constant demands for wyrdstone shipments. Average low skill is 95 gold (and I have the scholar veteran skill too), the higher level skills range to upwards of 280-300 gold. Even after completing a 259lb wyrdstone shipment I'm only able to pay for two or three skills before I'm in danger of not being able to pay for treatments, equipment loss, and upkeep. I suggest perhaps a separate currency system for skills? or a lowering of their price, or an increase in wyrdstone shipment payouts? Or maybe even just dropping the gold cost as you already require skill points themselves?

*Wyrdstone shipments come at regular intervals with increasing amount required and it is a great idea. It gives you a huge reason to harvest the pesky green crystals. However, the demand is a bit strenuous. It would be a lot easier to pay for skill upgrades and my warband in general if the demands weren't so constant. I love the system, but maybe a reprieve between shipments would help tremendously? Sometimes being able to send small shipments to one of the side smugglers helps out a lot, but then in doing so puts me behind the 8-ball on the next demand that comes within a day or two of the last completed.

Love the game, keep up the good work. I've got three open games going so I need to get back to my mercenaries. Look forward to updates and hopefully more warbands. (I'm looking at you Dwarves, Undead, Orks, elves (both kind), Witch Hunters, and *hopefully* lizardmen.)
