reviewText:
Pros:
-Tactical turn-based combat
-All choices are permanent; no save/reload/redo option
-Intelligent choices and patient tactics are rewarded
-Deep combat customization
-Fantastic gothic/dark atmosphere
-Four very different factions
-Well balanced
-Surprising level of appearance customization available
-High replayability

Cons:
-RNG hell, where you do everything right but your bruiser forgets how to stab correctly
-Initiative hell, where you lose three guys because the enemy group all goes first
-Steep learning curve that brutally punishes mistakes
-A good warband can be ruined by bad dice rolls
-AI is unimpressive

Overall: First, a disclaimer.  This game is brutal.  You cannot save or reload.  Everything that happens is permanent.  Your dual wielding commander loses an arm?  Tough break.  There is no way to go back before he lost an arm and redo things.  This warning is immediately followed by another - the game is ruled by dice rolls.  You can do everything correctly and still have your 84%-chance-to-hit killing blow miss three times in a row.  In those moments, you will hate this game.  The devil is in the dice, my friends.

Mordheim is based off of a tabletop game that I never played.  I just jumped right into this after seeing some youtube videos of it.  And I can say this - at least some of the reviewers who give this game negative reviews came here to rage-review after RNGesus abandoned them to their fates.  And it is incredibly rage-inducing.  But that is part of the allure of the game.  Eventually your warband WILL die, and after a point, that will only happen thanks to bad luck.  Accept it, embrace it, or don't waste your money.

The game is a dark, gritty, terrifying foray into a devastated city to recover magical space debris for your master of choice.  The plot serves mainly as a backdrop to the gameplay, which is unforgiving until you get the hang of it.  You make a group of fighters, take them on missions, try to accomplish any side objectives while killing the other guys, and if you're lucky, make it back with everyone alive and mostly intact.  Then you pay your guys, buy some better stuff, hire some replacement guys, and go back out again.  Every mission is a nail-biter because of just how much can go wrong.

It's fun.  For me, that's the selling point.  They nailed turn-based tactical gameplay.  Luck plays a role, but clever tactics play a much bigger role, and oftentimes you can make inferior numbers win through strategy.  They used the permanency mechanic to make it high-stakes, and I love it.  Sometimes the dice betray you, and sometimes they save you.  If you can get past that, then you'll likely find the same thing I did - a game you can keep playing for hours and hours on end.

Bottom Line: Recommended, but understand what you're buying - this game is not for the faint of heart.

reviewText:
Mordheim: City of the Damned is not for the faint of heart. It's tactical and relies on strategy and wit, but luck plays an important part, and it may not always be on your side. But if you're up for a gamble, then there's no denying it; Mordheim is one of my all-time favourite turn-based tactical rpg's.

Making good use of the Games Workshop franchise in terms of atmosphere and looks, the devs managed to create an extremely addictive and engaging game, which will gradually suck you in until there's no getting out. It's great fun to level up your soldiers and unlock skills that will offer whole new ways of approaching each match.

If you're a fan of games like X-Com, know that Mordheim does share a few similarities, but it's also very unique. It's much less forgiving of your mistakes, but it also feels much more rewarding when you are successful, as it really puts you to the test. If you're not afraid of trial & error, and occasionally getting your behind slapped by Lady Luck, then don't think twice and dive right in - this game is totally worth it.

Early Access Review

Its great to see Games Workshop are finaly branching their tabletop games and replicating them in desktop! So far im really enjoying the early access to this game.

Pros
Not bad graphics, would love to have a full HD option though and more intense visual options to put my computer to the test. (16gb gpu, 32gb ram, 4.8ghz i7... TEST ME BABY)

Multi layer gaming top! Fight from the sewers or the heights of ruined buildings sniping off your enemy. This makes the game really diverse in terms of tactics.

A never ending option of routes to flanking your enemy or achieving your objectives. There is no funneled gameplay which gives you the freedom you need!

Simulates accurately the tabletop game mechanics in every aspect, Fear checks, Moral.. etc

Cons
Picking up items and aquireing focus points doesnt seem to work at the moment or is too complicated to understand through the UI. Hopefully this will be fixed.

Camera Views can be quite anoying as you view the action from behind a wall (cant see anything) when fighting close to buildings.

Would be nice to see some new objectives rather than wipe out the enemy team.

So far though this early on in the access I loved the experience. Im really looking forward to future updates.

It is really refreshing to see this game aiming to stay so true to the original Mordheim games' rules. The turn-based action in this game really brings to life the strategy that was such a part of the game in its tabletop format. reviewText:
Solid Game, Turn based, Stratagy,

I have played this game for about a week now and have zero regrets in purchasing it. If you are a stratagy/tactics and warhammer fan this is a fantastic game for you.

This is a thinking persons game, its not a shooter or an action game it is fairly slow paced and methodical. if you dont use stratagy and tactics this game will be very frustrating for you. The AI isnt all that smart, but it is extreamly agressive, and can be very brutal when your not prepaired for it (learn to use this against it) even on the average dificuly maps.

PROS:
- Solid game, very few bugs
- fluid turn based gameplay
- Challenging
- good graphics and sound

CONS:
- early game can be pretty brutal
- AI is agressive, but not all that smart (see above)
- game modes are limited, very little variation except in story missions where you see some unique objectives
- warband customization is limited (I.E unit types)
- warband members can suffer permant injuries/death (as well as item/gear loss on being downed in combat)

reviewText:
A 3D, 3rd-Person, Turn-Based, Tactical, RPG set in the world of Warhammer Fantasy. Mordheim: City of the Damned has everything that I love in a game: a grim-dark universe rich with lore, simple controls, procedural encounters, customizable characters, and a difficulty that cannot be altered or lowered.
This game is hard, not because it requires skill but because every action taken by your characters, (walking is mundane and requires no actual roll), will be resolved randomly based on a percentage of your characters' skill; this percentage will be bigger or smaller from how high the skill is required to perform that action is. This means, you, as the player, have no actual control in how well your characters perform, the most that you, as the player, will be doing is moving your characters to an enemy and telling them to attack or up to a wall and telling them to climb it, all you can do is watch and hope they succeed. The player is soley responsible for strategy on the field and building up your warband to get better percentage rolls.
So let me reiterate, this game is hard, and you will become frustrated when you fail but the replayability for this game is extremely high and I advise playing as each of the available factions because they each require different types of mindsets to play them, and nothing feels better than settling with a race or faction that just speaks to you on an emotional level.

Anyways, I recommend this game to anyone who is a huge fan of unforgiving turn-based random number generators, meaning if you really liked Darkest Dungeon you are gonna enjoy this. I have been playing since the Cult of the Possessed were first added during Early Access so I am very pleased with how this game has evolved.
Oh and I highly recommend looking up the official lore and fluff for Warhammer Fantasy, you'll be suprised at how vast the universe can really be.
Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is easrly access. Very early. As it is it's not really worth getting. Buggy, bad interface, limit options. All the usual annoying EA problems that you would never want to see in the final game.

However, it shows real promise. So far the EA only really does the battle part of Mordhiem (which at most is only half of what makes Mordhiem what it is) but it's fun. It's a different take to the table top game but it works well and still feels liek Mordhiem. Tatics play a part but so does the dice roles, creating a rather good balance between strong positioning and risk vs reward.

Once they add more warbands, warband creation and injury/experiance, this could be a great game. And at 20% off right now, it's not a bad time to get into it. But if you do, you'll find only limited gameplay until more features are released.

One thing to remember is that they have changed a few things from the tabletop game, so look up the differences before buying. Also, only 4 warbands are going to be available on release (Human, Sisters, Prossessed and Skavan) but they are hoping to do more (currently that might be witch hunters and Undead!) A limited choice of warbands will hold this game back, so hopefully they release more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just to get it out of the way, *no* the game is not worth 20-30 dollars in it's current state. It's less an Alpha and more a 1v1 combat demo of the four warbands with no campaign or warband management that made the original Modheim, Necromunda, and Blood Bowl games so fun.

Is it worth the 20 dollars as a pre-order for the full game? I'd say yes.

The game is fun. I wasn't sure when I first saw the original videos, but it's a lot more of a tactical RTS game then you would think. Instead of player turns you go by unit initiative turns, and map vision is 100% based on your troops line of sight. They have changed the looting system to an almost scavanger hunt while in the middle of a PvP match - You now search for the warpstone and enemy chests during the fight, instead of getting a list of rewards after the match. Looting is also a team effort as each warrior of yours has 2 open inv spots, plus 1 extra spot per 4 str. So the entire warband will need to work on gathering the loot instead of having 1-2 packrats. The movement system is really simple to get the hang of as each point of movement your character has opens up a set distance shown in a blue ring, and as long as you don't run into an enemies range, you can always revert changes and move him in a different direction at any time. Combat reminds me of Fallout - each trooper seems to have 3-5 action points, and different combat maneuvers cost a different amount of your pool. When your warriors can actually gain xp and purchase skills and new equipment I could see this system being a helluva lot of fun.

I can't say anything about the magic as you basically get an attack spell and a buff spell and that's it. Again, when the warriors can be developed more I could see this system being fun, but right now it's just a fancy bowman.

Multiplayer is less fun. It's a bit buggy, it's full of a lot of rage quits right now, and since there is no warband progression 99% of what makes these types of games great is missing. In a patch or two when they hopefully have the xp system working and people start forming leagues, multiplayer will be worth it. Right now, I can't say it's a selling point.

The fact it's shipping with only four warbands (more will come via paid DLC I am sure. :/  ) is dissapointing as well. With all the great races and backstory the Warhammer world has, you would at least have hoped to see one of the Dwarven warband types, along with one of the Elven warband types, included in the base game. As it stands you basically get the Germans, the Joan of Arcs, Humans-but-cultists, and the awesome Skaven (rat assassins).

reviewText: I can't even begin to describe how frustrating this game is.  The worst part about it is that I like this style of game, and I desperately want to like this one, but I just can't because it's not honest.  The roll system in this game indicates a percentage likelihood to succeed in any given task, so when I have 7 people who all have a greater than 75% chance to hit their targets and I hit twice in 3 rounds, I have a problem.  If this was one scenario then I'd write it off as a set of bad rolls, but it's not just one scenario.  As the Skaven, who have the best agility, I failed 7 out of 8 of the agility tests I tried with over 70% chance to succeed.  As the mercenaries who have the best ballistics skills starting out, I never hit once with a ranged weapon.  The Sisters of Sigmar were the group I had the best luck with and I did that by tanking and trading blows, but that only works when you can actually hit at the rate you're supposed to.  So take any given % chance they show you and subtract somewhere between 20 and 50 from it and you'll have the actual rate of success.  If the numbers were accurate I'd love this game.  Instead I hate it because I'm constantly expecting what it tells me.\n\nEdit:  I've forced myself to continue playing in order to get my money's worth, and while I still don't recommend the game, I do have some more insight into it now.  I'm leaving my initial review because most of what was said still stands and it accurately portrays the frustration I felt upon initially starting the game.  I've since found that the game seriously suffers from an inverse difficulty curve where the game is extremely difficult for people who haven't put any time into it yet.  The more you play the more bonuses you get for both existing and new warbands.  This means that warbands you start later will have fewer starting problems, mostly that they won't feel forced to take missions that feel outside of their level.  The issues with rng still exist at higher levels.  When I have a skill that initally has a 75% chance to succeed and I cast it 3 times at base and 2 times with a plus 15% chance to succeed and I only get one success and 3 divine wrath" results that basically end that characters turn (and the divine wrath chance was only 15% chance on each cast) I feel as though instead of being told my success rate I'm being told my failure rate.  I understand that the game is supposed to be difficult
date: but there is definitely something wrong with the rng.  I'm even contemplating keeping track of everything I do to see just how far off the percentages are.  The game can become enjoyable
hoursPlayed: but it just takes too much effort to really be worth it in my opinion."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well.
This game shows a lot of potential.
Of course it's early access and so some of my critique may quickly become obsolete .

Strategy combat around city scapes where you can climb, drop and leap is a lot of fun.
Even though I am ignorant to Mordheim I greatly enjoy fantasy and this game has bucketloads of it.
A nice choice of starting warbands although I am a bit unsure about the lack of female mercenaries ( I wouldn't use them anyway but I find it odd) Perhaps there is a lore based reason?  Great potential for future growth.

The ambience and atmosphere of the game is great however I am not too sure about the suitability of the soundtrack.
While I think the soundtrack is quality it sounds like the drums of war and great battles at points. But these aren't great battles: they are skirmishes for ones life in the dregs of a corrupted world.   Anyway it seems insignificant. Stylised music for each warband would be great also. Ironically the opening menu ambience is fantastic but it does not seem to be replicated in skirmishes.

At the moment the games engine doesn't seem quite capable of supporting itself and I would highly recommend the coders get their butts in gear as to fixing critical game glitches for example playing versus  player seems to get stuck and 4/5 times will not get unstuck and you are left thinking of what might have been. Load times that don't seem to be done justice by the in game content.

There are some minor graphical glitches  mostly in chraracter models. The human impressive unit looks bald from some angles if he has no headgear. The ogre has an invisible buttcrack when he's stunned. Sisters are miraculously empty on the inside of their armour and it's particularly evident when they fail a drop check. Brethrens robes spazzing out.  Overall the graphics are solid, stylised and make a positive impact on the game.

Quite a few quality of life problems and glitches that need to be fixed up. There are spots in the map that are bugged one way or another. For example in the sewers of the church of sigmar there is a reddish tentacle-ridden area that one of my sisters got stuck in. There are multiple places where, as a ranged attacker, you can walk up a wall and get stuck in it for an added height boost and sniper spot particularly in houses of the merchants quarter. Seems to be a few problems with characters magically falling down walls they just climbed.  And the menus in skirmishes could really do with full mouse capabilities.

There are people who are griping and giving this game a bad rap. You must understand that there will always be people who give a game a bad rap and in the last 5 years they seem to have crawled out from under every rock and basement known to man.  If you have a reasonable intellect you can master the keyboard menus quite easily. The game is quite the very definition of early access and an excellent early access game with the promise of great growth potential for 2v2 and great customisation and strategy.

However I'm extremely fearful that this game will collapse or I will have to boycott it because it will become a left right and centre cash grab. Indeed, the game already shows omens of it in the form of currencies of wydrstone and coins. The Smugglers Den". The potential to buy boosts for your characters for exp and expedite their learning of new spells.
Purchashing mercenaries (Priest of Morr etc)

Finally the release is here.

This games scratches an itch I have had for years.  Turn based combat - with character growth, and character injury.

The first time your veteran loses an arm, a leg, or an eye - you will feel it.

The first time your one armed veteran returns to action and shows he still has what it takes, you will feel pride in this little digital warrior - or you'll use him for fodder.

The game has great atmosphere, decent art, decent sound, and amazing gameplay.  It does have a small campaign available for each warband that mixes things up a little bit.

I have just really enjoyed my time searching and scavenging the city of Mordheim.  I have recommended this game to several people at work who have bought it and also have enjoyed it.


If the devs read this, here is my wishlist:
- more customization options, I would even be willing to pay for this.
- new art for blue and purple items compared to white items
- birght wizards!
- more warbands

ah you know - just keep adding on to this amazing game.  I look forward to seeing what else is coming!

I've had great moments in this game, even though at the time of writing this review, the game is far from complete. But I can see myself playing this game, until it is complete and allows me to manage my troops through an evolutive process.

Mordheim is a game in the spirit of the many Warhammer themed games that already exists. The World of Warhammer is a grim world where life has no value and everyone, from the greatest hero to the lowest of the low, can die in an instant. It shall be the same with your troops. They will get hurt, light and grave, they will die. You will loose your Champions, but if you play your cards right, you will prevail ... at least that's how I hope the game will shape up to be ... like its tabletop equivalent, up there with tabletop Bloodbowl !

Edit: I have now come back to Mordheim: City of the Damned after its launch. This is the game I expected so this review remains positive ! I'll give you my pros and cons:

PROS:
- Turned based epic fights
- Character progression coupled with injury/death system that can be ruthless if you really are unlucky (your favorite hero/leader might die or have permanent injuries each time they are put out of action ... of they might get lucky and miraculously recover) ... don't put all your eggs in the same basket and you might want to wait until your characters are better equipped before training them for this 200 gold skill ...
- The maps are fun. There's a lot of terrain to cover and you'd best remember to manage movements tactically.
- Warband progression is, overall, very slow but I consider this a pro since it rewards long term planning and strategy. Bad luck can really mess with your plans ... but we accept that as one of the reasons we play such a game in the first place.

CONS:
- Long loading times. I understand the scale of the map and that warband generation is a complicated process but ... I can't imagine people at minimum requirements not ending up losing patience.
- Random numbers generation (dice rolls) is weird. This game gives us percentages but I feel like it rolls d4s in its tests. It's come to the point where I started rolling dice as I made my throws for a couple games, to compare and I wish I could play with dice ... they never gave me 6 misses in a row twice in a game on 84% chances to hit, my dice respect statistics a lot more than the game seems to be doing. I mention this only because I'm usually very good at risk assesment in such games but I'm now almost convinced I have to threat a 75% chance of success more like a 40% chance of success when taking decisions. Is that only me ?
- The user interface and user experience could easily be vastly improved. Menus could be arranged differently so that there's no counter intuitive stuff such as a list of incoming events in the Mission Selection screen (there could be a general information" menu for that and other informations spread around different menus). The "Warband management" menu where you pay for treatments and characters upkeep is a button just like other buttons. It could have its own menu or be a bit more evident

Very simplistic turn based stategy game, don't let that trick you into thinking it's easy. RNG rules and it doesn't favor you in the least apparent 80% will miss three times in a row for your warband but the AI doesn't seem to obey the rules of Chance.

But even if it did it serves to highlight the real problem with the game. The complete lack of depth to it's gameplay to give context, at the ten hour mark you may have characters with two or three abilities all behaving much the same. Some warbands have purely worse troops that still cost the same...management is shallow and limited, deployment is more often then not taken from you.

All the preparation in the world and all the careful management (or what little the game offers) matters little when all but moving your troops is reliant on a dice roll.

Other tactics games simply do more, often with much less powerful hardware.

The entire game seems like it was designed by a dev team who didn't know how to make a challengeing game but still wanted to plaster Hardcore" on eveything.

tl;dr There are very few features currently in the game, but what's there is very good and very promising.

So, point of mention: I never played Mordheim before this; I'm familiar with the game and its concept, but never had a chance to actually get in a campaign. Also note that this review is current as of the second content update

Currently the game only really has the combat more or less. There's 4 warbands (essentially Skaven, Empire, Warrior Priest Empire, and Chaos), and they all have unique units with different skills and abilities, including a powerful Leader unit and 1 impressive unit (Ogre, Chaos Spawn, Rat Ogre, or Super Sister) The rest of the options are fairly simple as to be expected from a starting warband, usually with only a skill or two differentiating them besides their different stat lines. Unfortunately, this does make the units feel very generic, but that's how I imagine they are until level ups and injuries anyways.

Surprisingly, combat/movement does not take place on a grid, but in 3D environments using circles to mark how far you can move with each movement point. This does create some weirdness moving around objectives, because you can end up eking out a lot more movement in some situations, looping around obstacles without leaving your circle, but largely looks really nice. The movement is also interestingly handled by WASD, so you actually get to run around with your guys, which was a refreshing change and felt really good. A nice side effect of this as well is that the entire game is playable with a gamepad, hinting that they may move into consoles at some point. reviewText: I have played over 30 hours of this game since it's offical release and I have enjoyed every minute of it. Yes the game does have it's glitches, which I hope the devleopers are looking into and going to try and fix, but I have seen few games roll out without a few glitches at release time. The game is unforgiving, but the table top game was just as unforgiving and I enjoy that part. It makes you feel like this mission could be your last so you need to use tactics to not just win, but to survive. If you run up and attack a whole warband with only one guy, well bad things are going to happen to your one guy. The game also makes you think about future missions. You can't just go and blow all your gold on members and equipment. You have to save money in case you need to replace that equipment or even replace a member who died or was too injuried to be worth using anymore. Luckily they have the reserve system, so members who are injuried can be put in reserve while they heal, or even train (yes training takes time in game also) and a fresh member can replace them. The controls are a little hard to get use to at first, but after a while playing the game, it became easier. While the load time is horrible and the AI seems to take forever to make its move during it's turn, it has yet to push me away from this game.  Overall, it is a good, horror filled game that you never know what is coming at you around a corner and you never know when it will be your last. If you enjoy these types of games or if you enjoyed the table top game, this is definitely one to pick up. I think you will enjoy it.

reviewText:
Great game with some bafflingly stupid design decisions. The developers have done an admirable job imitating the feel of the classic Mordheim miniatures game. The systems work well and there's some interesting decisions to be made once your warband gets past the first couple of missions and gain a few skills. Persistent injuries, forced ironman and your main income being what you scavenge in the middle of combat makes the campaign compelling even though it's mostly random missions. If you wanted a 50-50 mix of Blood Bowl and X-COM, this is it.

What pulls the game down is 3 things:
- Less-than-stellar (read: bloody stupid) AI. A big no-no in a strategy game
- Obscene waiting times. Maps take ages to load and if 3-4 enemies have a turn in succession you may as well tab out and watch a youtube video
- Godawful 3rd person camera and WASD movement. The game is practically begging for an isometric/eye-in-the-sky view.

If you can live with that, this is a solid game. Especially if you play it against people instead of the easily cheesable AI.

Mordheim City of the Damned is an excellent game.  Because I have crummy Internet I am not able to download it as quickly as I would like.  However, the patches for the game have been amazing.  I would reccomend it to anyone who likes nitty gritty turn based games.

My thoughts on the different warbands:

Cult of the Possessed: So far they are my favorite warband to play as.  They have good attacks, but lack in defense.  That is okay considering their henchmen start with two handed axes.  Thier leader starts out with a decent spell and their hero does have the chance of random mutations.

Clan Eshin: They are my second favorite to play even though they lack physical prowess.  They are not able to hit very hard, but their leader does start out with a poison weapon.  On the other hand, they are all excellent at dodges from the start making you harder to hit.

Sisters of Sigmar: The Sisters of Sigmar are the absolute worst warband to face in my opinion.  I have yet to win a battle against them and they all seem to be overpowered even at low levels.  When I try to play them, they always end up doing awful.  They seem to have a pretty good chance of doing well later on down the road though.

Mercenaries of Reikland: I have honestly not played them as I have never been a huge fan of the Empire.  I don't know all that much about them.

Overall, the game is very difficult to start, but it the game is very rewarding to players who do well.  The game itself is a little clunky, but it is a very good game.

So when I started out in this game I thought that maybe the naysayers had it right as it seemed ludicrously difficult, but 33 hours in and I love it.  It took me seven warbands to even get out of the blocks but that is becasue it is a learning experience.  Now I've got the hang of how to bring my squad together and focussing on preparing the battle ground that I want I can make pretty good progress.  That said it is still not a case of rinse and repeat.  If I make a mistake I get punished, and severley.  Yes the RNG can be punitive but it cuts both ways - Hero caught out in the open about to get mashed by a leader and hero from the enemy and then my lowly archer on the roof gets a stun on both bad guys in same round.  Without RNG that could never happen - I think the game gives you more extreme highs and lows as a result but I kind of like that.

My biggest problem so far is that I cannot for the life of me see how I will ever amass enough cash to be able to skill up - got tons of skill points available but never have any money to be able to apply them.  Maybe it will get better in time.  Always seem to end up in combat very quickly and get a rout before I collect a fraction of the loot.

I don't know the table top game or the Lore surrounding it but I hope we get DLC where I can have Greenskin and Ork warbands.  On warbands I should add that I'm not wild about the warband representations.  I've got a chaos crew who I think look the best of the bunch.  Think the Mercenaries (particularly the starting Hero unit) look like they'd fall over if you sneezed on them and why are there now mixed gender groupings?  Got to be boys or girls.

That said it's got me hooked so thumbs up.

reviewText:
This game is very good if you're not afraid to lose a few characters here and there. especially on your first playthrough.

People whine about the Random Number Generator because they missed a few hits in desperate situations, but my guess is they skipped statistics classes in college, and they shouldn't have put their characters in a desperate situation in the first place.

If you flip a coin five times and it lands on heads five time, you're not gonna claim you've solved the coin flipping rule of the universe.
Sometimes, in Mordheim COTD, you need to shackle the opponent's impressive character, but somehow your 95% succes chance Magister fails and gets stunned in front of everyone, and your poor sod facing the impressive character will have a bad time.
Sometimes though, you play tight and get a lucky crit on their most dangerous character, and turn a uneasy battle into a piece of cake.
You never hear people whine about lucky crits, though.

You could see this game as an XCOM set in the Warhammer world with a default hard difficulty (which isn't that hard once you get the hang of it).
Some of your characters will die, and that's ok, learn to manage a rooster big enough to handle those situations.

If you want a blissful experience without any character dying, stick to the first xcom reboot on easy difficulty.
Mordheim: COTD is beautiful, challenging and fun.

reviewText:
A fun game, albeit repetitive at times. I see many people complaining about the RNG, but it's all superficial: the RNG is fair. Heck, if you're a Blood Bowl veteran, you won't even bat an eye at the failed high percentage rolls.

Anyway, what is the game like? Take 1 X-Com, mix it very thoroughly with Valkyria Chronicles, and richly season with Warhammer.

Pros:

1. Warband Management is immensely satisfying. There are endless ways to build your warband, customize each warrior with skills, stats, equipment , etc. This is where the game really shines. Do not be put off by only four factions, as even with four factions the variety is mindboggling.

2. Combat is fun, and differs quite significantly from faction to faction. While the limited number of maps and objectives might get a little stale after a while, the actual process of chopping your opponents to pieces (or shooting them to tatters) doesn't get old.

3. Seamless integration of Single and Multiplayer combat. So you beat the main campaign, and routinely  trash the AI on every map. You're good, right? So you try a multiplayer battle and get your ♥♥♥ handed back to you on a platter. You lick your wounds, play a few more single player battles to get some money and replace lost equipment and crippled teammates, then you go back into MP and whoop somebody else. Or get whooped. Either way, well done.

Cons:
1. As I said earlier, there isn't a huge variety of maps and objectives. That hurts the game a little.

2. Minor graphic glitches and long loading times. Nothing gamebreaking, but somewhat annoying.

Final verdict.
Definitely get it if:
You are a fan of the Warhammer universe, or tactical squad based games or even Blood Bowl.

reviewText:
15 hours in and so far I can say that this game is quite punishing....but I am loving it.

You can recover from tactical mistakes, though the recovery can be painful.  Your warband has to be resilient, every diligent and most importantly....not too greedy!

As a long time fan of GW's Warhammer Fantasy this game definitely grabs the atmosphere of the Old World and smashes into your brain while you make a dizzying effort to navigate the streets of Mordheim.  Represented in this game currently are the forces of The Empire, Skaven, Cult of the Possessed, and the Sisters of Sigmar.  With those four factions there is tons of content already built into the game with a lot of replay factor that goes along with it all.

I purchased this game in its pre-order beta rough days and have watched it grow to become quite the diamond.  The devs have used their time judiciously and have listened to a lot of feedback in the process.

I am really hoping that this game grows in popularity, and that other faction's warbands get representation.  Dark Elves, Dwarves, Beastmen, Lizardmen (my favorite), Tomb Guardians, Witch Hunters (Empire), and you can't leave out Orcs!!!

All in all I give the game 4 out of 5.  The learning curve is steep, but to be honest, you can download the Mordheim Living manual and learn everything you need to know about game play and then find that the devs have done a great job representing the gameplay and concepts here.

For Sigmar!

reviewText:
The best multiplayer tactical turn-based strategy game I've ever encountered, bar none. As a lifelong devotee to the turn-based classics like XCOM, Jagged Alliance and Silent Storm, I've always wanted the beauty of Necromunda's consequence-laden multiplayer skirmishes brought to the PC - and this game delivers.

After two days of owning the title, I've accumulated 17 hours of multiplayer-only battles, and the matches I now have under my belt are without doubt the most memorable strategy gaming experiences I've ever had - even better than playing Necromunda with miniatures. Hell, I'm terrified this game will distract me from my own programming work!

As everybody will tell you, the third-person movement and control scheme will seem strange at first, but they serve to immerse you more; like how Firaxis' introduction of cinematic shots for dramatic moments did, but better. Warband management is the real-deal Necromunda/Mordheim experience; defeats and victories don't feel so black and white, as even a victor might walk away worse for wear, or - as is the case against a friend - economically poorer for not focusing on resources.

This is the first time I've ever felt compelled to write a review for a game, but as somebody who's been trying for years to find a multiplayer strategy experience that captures the nuances of the Necromunda/Mordheim systems, and as somebody who's programming a TBS myself, I desperately want this developer to succeed with this product and consider releasing a DLC for some of the fringe-factions.

I implore you to buy it, harass your friends to buy it, and start a small tourney where each of you has a warband that you only pit against each other in multiplayer. You'll have more fun than any other TBS game can offer you right now, at least in the multiplayer aspect.

reviewText:
A turn based strategy that has a collection of vastly different factions (dictating relative playstyle), the ability to fully customize your warband in terms of look, composition and even name, Hardcore gaming mechanics and character perma-death, and the ability to take your single player warband up against others in multiplayer and have those battles count towards experience and loot.  What's not to like?

This unforgiving game will not hold the punches, and has a learning curve that may cause some players to turn away but in terms of fully customizable Turn Based Strategy I would call this a true gem of the genre and a very fulfilling experience on the whole.  Each battle is tense and demands attention and understanding of your warband's abilities and limitations.  Much of the battle system relies on Random Generated Numbers (So as to stay true to the Game's Origins from Table Top), but in this game strategy is key as you attempt to navigate this deadly city and keep every party member as whole as possible.

In Mordheim there are no victors, just survivors.

reviewText:
15 hours in and so far I can say that this game is quite punishing....but I am loving it.

You can recover from tactical mistakes, though the recovery can be painful.  Your warband has to be resilient, every diligent and most importantly....not too greedy!

As a long time fan of GW's Warhammer Fantasy this game definitely grabs the atmosphere of the Old World and smashes into your brain while you make a dizzying effort to navigate the streets of Mordheim.  Represented in this game currently are the forces of The Empire, Skaven, Cult of the Possessed, and the Sisters of Sigmar.  With those four factions there is tons of content already built into the game with a lot of replay factor that goes along with it all.

I purchased this game in its pre-order beta rough days and have watched it grow to become quite the diamond.  The devs have used their time judiciously and have listened to a lot of feedback in the process.

I am really hoping that this game grows in popularity, and that other faction's warbands get representation.  Dark Elves, Dwarves, Beastmen, Lizardmen (my favorite), Tomb Guardians, Witch Hunters (Empire), and you can't leave out Orcs!!!

All in all I give the game 4 out of 5.  The learning curve is steep, but to be honest, you can download the Mordheim Living manual and learn everything you need to know about game play and then find that the devs have done a great job representing the gameplay and concepts here.

For Sigmar!

reviewText:
A fun game, albeit repetitive at times. I see many people complaining about the RNG, but it's all superficial: the RNG is fair. Heck, if you're a Blood Bowl veteran, you won't even bat an eye at the failed high percentage rolls.

Anyway, what is the game like? Take 1 X-Com, mix it very thoroughly with Valkyria Chronicles, and richly season with Warhammer.

Pros:

1. Warband Management is immensely satisfying. There are endless ways to build your warband, customize each warrior with skills, stats, equipment , etc. This is where the game really shines. Do not be put off by only four factions, as even with four factions the variety is mindboggling.

2. Combat is fun, and differs quite significantly from faction to faction. While the limited number of maps and objectives might get a little stale after a while, the actual process of chopping your opponents to pieces (or shooting them to tatters) doesn't get old.

3. Seamless integration of Single and Multiplayer combat. So you beat the main campaign, and routinely  trash the AI on every map. You're good, right? So you try a multiplayer battle and get your ♥♥♥ handed back to you on a platter. You lick your wounds, play a few more single player battles to get some money and replace lost equipment and crippled teammates, then you go back into MP and whoop somebody else. Or get whooped. Either way, well done.

Cons:
1. As I said earlier, there isn't a huge variety of maps and objectives. That hurts the game a little.

2. Minor graphic glitches and long loading times. Nothing gamebreaking, but somewhat annoying.

Final verdict.
Definitely get it if:
You are a fan of the Warhammer universe, or tactical squad based games or even Blood Bowl.

reviewText: I'm really surprised by this game, I might go back and do a far more analytical review but for now I'll say this. I was expecting this game to either me meh or just be another cash in. What I got was a beautiful turn based experience where I feel attached to my men and women, without ever feeling cheated like I do in XCOM and Blood Bowl. Everything you do means something and you need to meet a deadline so it gains quite a lot in terms of down to the wire moments. In a mission I took on because I thought I might be able to handle it when it was higher difficulty, I found myself cut short as I barely scraped out a win and had a lot of injuries and had to wait for them to get better. I wasn't confident in going without a full squad but even when I wanted to, you can't leave to a mission without your leader being healed up. So I had to wait till there was two days left since my leader just recovered his injuries. Since then I keep referring to this moment during dark times as the moment we had to 'Break Bad' and take everything we could of warpstone even if it meant using some units to draw aggro away and perhaps have a chance to save the sacrificial lambs later once we recovered all the warp stone.

reviewText:
Very slick X-COM style game inspired by Games Workshop's Mordheim.

Pros:
Permanent consequences force strategic and tough choices
LOTS of skills, upgrades and units
4 initiatal warbands feel and play differently despite strong overlaps
It is faithful to original mordheim without being stuck to D6's

Cons:
AI can be pretty stupid
It's mordheim, prepare to HATE random chance.  (As a table top player, it was far far worse)
-You'll miss key rolls to hit, climb, or cast spells
-Your favorite character will die
-You'll be on a roll then the next encounter is AMBUSH and suddenly all tactics are out the windo
(This can suck by modern gaming standards, but that's part of the charm of the original)
Loading times are stupid long - apparently nearly every aspect of map and oppenents team is randomly generated on the spot
Early campaign is boring.  You need at least 3-5 games before you get enough skills to build a warband to your liking and not just vanilla.  Once you hit level 3, then you're going places.

Overall, I would strongly recommend this game to roguelike fans, strategy game enthusiasts or nostalgic games workshop players.  It's not perfect, but its one of my favorits.

reviewText:
Every update this game becomes more and more like what I originally hoped it would be.

Pros
+It's a Mordheim video game, and it is good. If you understand what that means, this should be an auto-purchase.
+First person turn based works awesomely, I've never seen it done like this before and I think it really fits the game. The developers clearly put a lot of work into those environments (They look amazing) and first person really compliments that well.
+All 4 Warbands are interesting and fun in their own way. Even the humans (Very rare for GW media)
+Good variety of skills/spells, good character progression as well. It's fairly similar to XCom
+Vertical movement almost as important as horizontal. Very unique to Mordheim I think, and its very fun
+Fun as ♥♥♥♥. Really the most important thing.
+I'd imagine finding a group of people to play a large scale multiplayer campaign (Like you could on the tabletop) would be fun. I don't have any friends though, so that's just me theorizing

Cons
-Only 4 war bands without that many kinds of units.
-Campaign nothing special (not that this is meant to be played for the story lol) collecting wyrdstone can be annoying and they make you do it
-The UI is very strange and almost feels like it was designed for consoles?



I'm hoping more war bands come out soon, because right now that's really the big flaw for me. There simply isn't enough variety within warbands themselves to justify only having 4 and calling this a finished game.

reviewText:
I dont write too many reviews unless the is incredibly bad or amazing. This game is the latter.. AMAZING. Mordheim takes the combat system of Valkyria: Chronicles, the unit customization of X-Com, psychology system of darkest dungeon, the unforgivability of an Ironman Mode and throws into a interesting story with an immersive atmosphere. As a note, I'm not a fan of 40k/warhammer etc. and have never played the tabletop.. Yet I love this game. I'd write more but I linked a video below that says it all.

TL;DR -

Pro's -
RPG progression
Great Combat System
Unit Movement is intuitive
In-game Currency/Management system is well balanced
PvP is intense
Real concequences
Good Story
Amazing Aestetics
Immersive atmosphere
Good Customization of Units

Cons -
AI is stupid
Steep Learning Curve
Ironman Mode
Continuous Autosave prevents you from taking back a mistake

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X2qe6yY6aL0

There is a very steep learning curve which may put off the majority of casual players. I went through about 30 hours of loosing my entire warband (4 restarts) and having to start all over before I finally achieved a successful combination of soldiers. Of course once I learned the basics.. exploiting the AI became incredibly easy. 98% success rate on missions. Which leaves PvP for the challenge, and yes it is a challenge with real rewards and real consequences.

The Ironman mode you will find yourself in is Unforgiving. If your character gets critically hit (your standard high dmg crit in any game) he will suffer a permanent injury. By permanent injury, I mean he will loose an eye and have -10% chance to hit for the rest of the game, or loose an arm and never be able to dual wield or use a 2hander. He could loose a leg and never be able to climb again (Which is really important in this game). You will find yourself becoming the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ company man and firing any worker who gets hurt lol.

The movement system is amazing, just like in valkyria chronicles. You will recieve strategy points which can be used for certain types of active skills (Parry stance, climb, leap, jump down, etc.) or for movement. Each character has it's own movement radius based on his agility stats and gear equiped. Movement itself consumes 1 point giving you a radius to within, moving past the radius consumes another strategy point automatically. Early in the game you will have 4-6 strategy points while fully leveled up characters will have 7-12 points. Didnt get to the position you wanted this turn? Simply run back through your waypoints and get your Strategy points refunded.

The combat system is amazing

reviewText:
A fun game, albeit repetitive at times. I see many people complaining about the RNG, but it's all superficial: the RNG is fair. Heck, if you're a Blood Bowl veteran, you won't even bat an eye at the failed high percentage rolls.

Anyway, what is the game like? Take 1 X-Com, mix it very thoroughly with Valkyria Chronicles, and richly season with Warhammer.

Pros:

1. Warband Management is immensely satisfying. There are endless ways to build your warband, customize each warrior with skills, stats, equipment , etc. This is where the game really shines. Do not be put off by only four factions, as even with four factions the variety is mindboggling.

2. Combat is fun, and differs quite significantly from faction to faction. While the limited number of maps and objectives might get a little stale after a while, the actual process of chopping your opponents to pieces (or shooting them to tatters) doesn't get old.

3. Seamless integration of Single and Multiplayer combat. So you beat the main campaign, and routinely  trash the AI on every map. You're good, right? So you try a multiplayer battle and get your ♥♥♥ handed back to you on a platter. You lick your wounds, play a few more single player battles to get some money and replace lost equipment and crippled teammates, then you go back into MP and whoop somebody else. Or get whooped. Either way, well done.

Cons:
1. As I said earlier, there isn't a huge variety of maps and objectives. That hurts the game a little.

2. Minor graphic glitches and long loading times. Nothing gamebreaking, but somewhat annoying.

Final verdict.
Definitely get it if:
You are a fan of the Warhammer universe, or tactical squad based games or even Blood Bowl.

reviewText:
15 hours in and so far I can say that this game is quite punishing....but I am loving it.

You can recover from tactical mistakes, though the recovery can be painful.  Your warband has to be resilient, every diligent and most importantly....not too greedy!

As a long time fan of GW's Warhammer Fantasy this game definitely grabs the atmosphere of the Old World and smashes into your brain while you make a dizzying effort to navigate the streets of Mordheim.  Represented in this game currently are the forces of The Empire, Skaven, Cult of the Possessed, and the Sisters of Sigmar.  With those four factions there is tons of content already built into the game with a lot of replay factor that goes along with it all.

I purchased this game in its pre-order beta rough days and have watched it grow to become quite the diamond.  The devs have used their time judiciously and have listened to a lot of feedback in the process.

I am really hoping that this game grows in popularity, and that other faction's warbands get representation.  Dark Elves, Dwarves, Beastmen, Lizardmen (my favorite), Tomb Guardians, Witch Hunters (Empire), and you can't leave out Orcs!!!

All in all I give the game 4 out of 5.  The learning curve is steep, but to be honest, you can download the Mordheim Living manual and learn everything you need to know about game play and then find that the devs have done a great job representing the gameplay and concepts here.

For Sigmar!

reviewText:
Very slick X-COM style game inspired by Games Workshop's Mordheim.

Pros:
Permanent consequences force strategic and tough choices
LOTS of skills, upgrades and units
4 initiatal warbands feel and play differently despite strong overlaps
It is faithful to original mordheim without being stuck to D6's

Cons:
AI can be pretty stupid

-You'll miss key rolls to hit, climb, or cast spells
-Your favorite character will die
-You'll be on a roll then the next encounter is AMBUSH and suddenly all tactics are out the windo
(This can suck by modern gaming standards, but that's part of the charm of the original)
Loading times are stupid long - apparently nearly every aspect of map and oppenents team is randomly generated on the spot
Early campaign is boring.  You need at least 3-5 games before you get enough skills to build a warband to your liking and not just vanilla.  Once you hit level 3, then you're going places.

Overall, I would strongly recommend this game to roguelike fans, strategy game enthusiasts or nostalgic games workshop players.  It's not perfect, but its one of my favorits.

So when I started out in this game I thought that maybe the naysayers had it right as it seemed ludicrously difficult, but 33 hours in and I love it.  It took me seven warbands to even get out of the blocks but that is becasue it is a learning experience.  Now I've got the hang of how to bring my squad together and focussing on preparing the battle ground that I want I can make pretty good progress.  That said it is still not a case of rinse and repeat.  If I make a mistake I get punished, and severley.  Yes the RNG can be punitive but it cuts both ways - Hero caught out in the open about to get mashed by a leader and hero from the enemy and then my lowly archer on the roof gets a stun on both bad guys in same round.  Without RNG that could never happen - I think the game gives you more extreme highs and lows as a result but I kind of like that.

My biggest problem so far is that I cannot for the life of me see how I will ever amass enough cash to be able to skill up - got tons of skill points available but never have any money to be able to apply them.  Maybe it will get better in time.  Always seem to end up in combat very quickly and get a rout before I collect a fraction of the loot.

I don't know the table top game or the Lore surrounding it but I hope we get DLC where I can have Greenskin and Ork warbands.  On warbands I should add that I'm not wild about the warband representations.  I've got a chaos crew who I think look the best of the bunch.  Think the Mercenaries (particularly the starting Hero unit) look like they'd fall over if you sneezed on them and why are there now mixed gender groupings?  Got to be boys or girls.

That said it's got me hooked so thumbs up.

reviewText:
This game is very good if you're not afraid to lose a few characters here and there. especially on your first playthrough.

People whine about the Random Number Generator because they missed a few hits in desperate situations, but my guess is they skipped statistics classes in college, and they shouldn't have put their characters in a desperate situation in the first place.

If you flip a coin five times and it lands on heads five time, you're not gonna claim you've solved the coin flipping rule of the universe.
Sometimes, in Mordheim COTD, you need to shackle the opponent's impressive character, but somehow your 95% succes chance Magister fails and gets stunned in front of everyone, and your poor sod facing the impressive character will have a bad time.
Sometimes though, you play tight and get a lucky crit on their most dangerous character, and turn a uneasy battle into a piece of cake.
You never hear people whine about lucky crits, though.

You could see this game as an XCOM set in the Warhammer world with a default hard difficulty (which isn't that hard once you get the hang of it).
Some of your characters will die, and that's ok, learn to manage a rooster big enough to handle those situations.

If you want a blissful experience without any character dying, stick to the first xcom reboot on easy difficulty.
Mordheim: COTD is beautiful, challenging and fun.

reviewText:
This is a good turn based tactics and strategy game that makes you feel more involved with the party you lead than any conversation simulator (mass effect cough cough, dragon age, cough cough).
Its not that hard, its unforgiving with the dead and the missing limbs but its doable. The graphics are not super duper but in fact they are good because they chose to use an art style depicting ugly faces and dirty looks rather than a cartoonish shiny clean design such as world of warcraft or lets admit it, bioware recent games. In that regard they remain quite loyal to what you could expect from warhammer fantasy.
There aint much customization or cosmetic options lets face it, and there is no open world as such to explore. Instead you got a city in ruins and you make daily runs to gather stones, weapons and scavenge whatever you can while trying to saty alive. A bit like holidays in Chernobyl. With ratmen. And chaos followers, and feminazi women, and some men inbetween (4 factions: skaven ratmen, chaos cultists, sisters of something holy and human mercenaries -the good guys-).
The campaign offers an open ending allowing you to continue playing and customizing your ideal warband in whatever way you want (there are  a lot of interesting builds and things to experiment with in the 10 levels each character can get). And this is for me one of the best aspects of the game which made me decide to buy it.
The combat itself is completelly turn based, despite some videos showing the typical wasd movement (which is a translation of the tabletop game of your hand moving the miniatures using their available strategy points).
The story, while simple (simple is bestest) is quite interesting: you lead a warband and you gather STUFF while putting your life at risk to sell it to rich people who, in exchange, pays you a misery or kills you if you do not get the stone orders in time.  Genius.
For me most of the fun of this game, apart of the combat and feeling of total loss when one of my men dies is the histories you can imagine yourself while playing a hard match and managing to survive or at least win marginally to return to your base with a bunch of wyrdstone, and one or two arms less. You get to like each and every one of your mercenaries or ratmen or whatever fantasy fetish stereotype you are into.

I know its a bit messy review but most of the good things have been said in other posts so you can read those too.

All in all, probably my best purchase of 2015 in terms of raw pure fun and 0 dissapointment.
Totally recomended as long as you are slightly patient and dont have mental issues with RNG. This is the kind of game you can play and stop whenever you want to do any real life thing or just stay playing telling yourself just one more turn". It has some ocassional bugs but nothing a reload cant fix (for me at elast)."

You are bothered by relatively big flaws
You dislike slow paced games
You dislike repetitives missions without much substance
Its confusing, every part of it, you have to experiement and learn by yourself. At the beguinning you will restart your warband often. The ingame interface is alright, but the warband management interface is clunky. Its a good game, for those who have a lot of time to spare. Its really in multiplayer that the gameplay shine, because the AI is pretty dumb and have its statistics padded to compensate. So best way to have fun is to have friends or join a clan.

Also, a second screen is higly suggested or play in windowed because the loadings take forever and while you wait for the other non-visibile warband to do their thing you will want to keep your mind occupied during all these waiting periods.

Mordheim: City of the Damned is a Masochist wet dream.

This game is possibly the funnest time you will have getting your a** handed to you on a silver platter especially late game. This game has a entire list of just painful factors that'll leave you rage quiting after every game you play, but like an abused girlfriend, you'll just keep coming back for more hoping to pull off those tight decisive victories and bloody battles that make you cheer alongside your warband.

Now Mordheim is a game that doesn't go easy on you and one bad mistake could cause your entire warband to be brutally defeated and lose you the game. Not a problem, but you'll be fighting against harsh RNG that definitely favors the AI in most fights. Good news though, the enemy warband can also break, instantly winning you the battle. The Bad news is if the enemy breaks, you lose out on completing any optional objectives that are vital for leveling up your warband. Complete optional objectives before you fight" I hear you say

reviewText: This is the first game i've taken the time to review on steam.  I would love to recommend it to people, but sadly i cannot in its current form.  If your looking for a game that is fair or at the least plays by the same rules you have to, then keep moving.  This game is designed from the ground up to be unfair towards the player.  All because they are unable to make an even remotely decent A.I.  You WILL miss 9/10 attacks, even when they have a 95% chance to hit,  Meanwhile the enemy will roll 5's all day so they get multiple criticals and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t hits in a row.  I don't have a problem with RNG.  It is obvious however when playing this game that the deck is severaly stacked.  I wouldn't doubt if there is a 50% chance on every roll to add 30 or more to your roll.  You will NEVER roll a 1 or anything near it.  You will however roll 85-95 on every other roll.  This wouldn't be a problem if they allowed you to choose if you wanted high or low rolls to be good, however that is sadly not the case.  On top of that, every match that you do really well on(complete all the objectives/no one is taken out of action) you will,for no reason, still have 1-3 heros with wounds that have to sit out for several days.   In case you are wondering if im just a baddie at the game, i have yet to lose a round yet.  Despite all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that causes me to curse and scream in fury at this game, it still cant manage to beat me.  Thats how BAD the A.I is.  They will walk the opposite direction of the nearest ally/enemy fighting to go stand in a random doorway and try to ambush something. Despite the fact no one is in that direction.  This means instead of feeling like you had a good match, or that perhaps you made a mistake and could learn from it and improve, you instead just got RNG'd.  The same goes for improving your characters.  You want to put a hero in heavy armor? Well, too bad.  You sure as hell aren't gonna be able to buy it from the shop.  Wanna two-handed sword instead of an axe? Well, F*ck you.  You damn better hope an enemy in one of the upcoming matches has one, and is stupid enough to rush you by himself so that after killing him you can actually loot the body.  Cause if his teamates are around you wont be able to stand close enough to loot it,  Do you want a specific enchant on your weapon or armor? Again, you can just f*ck off.  There is an amazing amount of them to choose from.  To bad they only way to get them is RNG from a mission reward unless you just so happen to want one of the horrible ones offered by the other factions.   Also what the hell is with the RNG time on deleveries?  Sure the last time you sent a shipment to the pit you were paid the next day.  This time?   Well its gonna take about 3 days.  Really?  You will never have enough gold to train the skills and spellls you want.  You will find yourself selling a ridiculous amount of looted treasure and stone, just to pay and heal up the scrubs on your team that get injured from stubbing their toe,  On top of that, why the hell do i have to pay these idiots AND supply the equipment for em?  Can they not supply their own tools/weapons and armor? Maybe the fact i've paid these idiots in the neighborhood of 500g a piece would mean they could pay for their own damn training and weapons?  Also spellcasting is useless in this game, unless you consider risking doing 9999 damage to yourself to MAYBE succeed in casting a spell that MIGHT reduce a random stat.(or other equally uselss spell.)  I kid you not.  Not even the 10th time i try to cast a spell and my only caster,and leader, manages to one shot himself.  I mean come the hell on.  Meanwhile the only negative you will ever see an enemy caster get is the on that just so happens to stun himself and EVERYONE near him.  Oh

reviewText: Don't buy this game.  It's actually worse than if it was just awful because it's just good enough to convince you to invest hours into it only to set you in a horribly lopsided scenario where you watch helplessly as all the heroes you've worked hard to build up are mercilously beaten down in situation so one-sided as to leave you completely helpless.  Then watch them die and become disfigured rendering your whole warband essentially worthless.  You could argue this is an attempt to reflect the Mordheim miniature game, which can be pretty brutal, but knowing it is pretty brutal, in the miniature game you can volentarily rout a mission pretty early on when you see the situation is hopeless and minimize casualties.  This game forces you to continue suffering a beat down until nearly all your forces are taken out.\n\nI like a challenge, I like the gritty nature of the Mordheim world, but I have too much to do and too many games to choose from to invest hours of my life into something that crushes your efforts that callously and so do you.

reviewText: Okay so this game is really good at its core gameplay! but only to a point I mean so basically the only way to be able to play on equal grounds with your friends is to make brand new warbands or use Exploits which I will not mention due to the fact they're a must to have a warband that isn't completely maimed after a certain point because the Smuggler's Den system is absolutely insane, You can actually drain a map entirely of its resource of Wyrdstone several matches in a row and that won't even be enough sometimes and having to put my units in danger to get Wyrdstone because of the fact that They're in even more danger if I don't fill out those orders the warband will shatter in time. reviewText:
i like that we are now getting good games in the warhammer universe, and hoped that this game would be played alongside vermintide. unfortunetely the pure RNG in this game is a huge turnoff for me.

the good

-good graphics and art style: the world is well realised and everything fits well with the theme of a city distorted by wyrdstone.

-wide range of tactic choices: i enjoy how unique the different factions feel, i unfortunetely didint get deep into this aspect as i wanted to refund this game, but what was there was good.

the bad

- the load times are long: i have a fairly fast SSD and this game still takes multiple minutes to get into a level, to the point i frequently tabbed out and watched videos while waiting for the music changes to let me know the loading was done.

-slow paced: the game takes a long time to get going, and most of the time you spend the first 2-3 turns just running towards objectives not knowing where your opponent is going to be.

-unclear RNG mechanic: i enjoy games that use risk management as a primary mechanic, but this game is really bad at giving you all the numbers to make an informed dicision. sometimes you will miss repeatedely with 80% to hit, is flanking usefull at all? etc.

-bland warband management and custimization: th amount of freedom you get with your warband is limited, perhaps later on this is expanded, but going 3 missions in and replacing a character with clones of himself is dull and none of the units feels unique. i was also dissapointed the the extent of the costimization options are colors.

reviewText: I am glad that a company took the time to take an older game that wasnt avaible to the masses and port it to the PC, and I have spent many hours playing this game. This is coming from someone who has spent over 200 hours playing Xcom Longwar, And I can honestly say it feels as though the chance system should be reviewed. I would not recommend this to people unfamilar with this system, But overall I feel it is a good game.

reviewText:
i like that we are now getting good games in the warhammer universe, and hoped that this game would be played alongside vermintide. unfortunetely the pure RNG in this game is a huge turnoff for me.

the good

-good graphics and art style: the world is well realised and everything fits well with the theme of a city distorted by wyrdstone.

-wide range of tactic choices: i enjoy how unique the different factions feel, i unfortunetely didint get deep into this aspect as i wanted to refund this game, but what was there was good.

the bad

- the load times are long: i have a fairly fast SSD and this game still takes multiple minutes to get into a level, to the point i frequently tabbed out and watched videos while waiting for the music changes to let me know the loading was done.

-slow paced: the game takes a long time to get going, and most of the time you spend the first 2-3 turns just running towards objectives not knowing where your opponent is going to be.

-unclear RNG mechanic: i enjoy games that use risk management as a primary mechanic, but this game is really bad at giving you all the numbers to make an informed dicision. sometimes you will miss repeatedely with 80% to hit, is flanking usefull at all? etc.

-bland warband management and custimization: th amount of freedom you get with your warband is limited, perhaps later on this is expanded, but going 3 missions in and replacing a character with clones of himself is dull and none of the units feels unique. i was also dissapointed the the extent of the costimization options are colors.

This will be short, cause I'm not a pro at this.

reviewText:
If you were expecting a faithful interpretation of the original tabletop game then prepare for disappointment for this is not the game you're looking for. The only similarities between this game and the original are that you're playing a warband management and battle game that has character progression, random loot tables and is set in GW universe's Mordheim. Deeper inspection, however, reveals that even these shared attributes are more dissimilar than they are similar.

I'll start with my number one grievance with the game that is also the main thing you'll spend your time on: combat.

The combat in the tabletop Mordheim is about odds calculation, risk assessment and careful positioning that aims to maximize the risks your opponent must take while minimizing your own. There's strategic beauty and elegance to this general concept that reveals itself to you when you start to comprehend the multitude of variables and see the matrix open before your eyes.

In the PC game, however, you have no easy way of assessing how far you can move and you have no idea about the ranges of attacks and abilities. The camera is set behind the character whose turn it is, and despite the function that lets you see the entire map from above, you generally struggle to get an idea where you are and how to get where you want. Often you waste several turns just trying to navigate out of a multi-level house because there are only couple of set points you can jump down from and you can't openly inspect the map to find them. Sufficient information is simply not provided to you, which forces you to adapt a trial and error approach, which erodes any strategic merits the game might have otherwise had.

The game also uses its own way of calculating hit chance, damage, armor saves, stats and even health that differ entirely from the tabletop game, making the game less accessible for us experienced with tabletop Mordheim.  Fair enough, the tabletop version is by no means perfect, byt why would you replace that system with something alien, more complex, and arguably, even worse?

As if all of this wasn't enough the developers also added a horrible UI that makes even the simple task of charging an enemy a fiddly process that requires you to move your character back and forth to find the right distance from the enemy to enable the action. Each character also has their own 'bubble' that stops you from taking actions if you enter them, making positioning a constant nightmare, especially since, as mentioned above, you have no sense of ranges.

And then we have the A.I... I really don't get it why the devs get this so wrong so often. No, you can't make up for bad A.I. by giving it an artificial advantage over the player in form of better stats and gear. That's the cheap way of doing it and ends up with A.I. that is is incredibly unrewarding and frustrating to face but at the same time easily abuseable. I'd go so far as to say that even if all the other issues were ignored the terrible state of the A.I. alone makes the campaign mode unplayable.

The final insult to us who now prefer PC versions over the tabletop games because the real life version takes too much time, is make us wait for the A.I. to finish all its moves, slowly, one character at a time, even when the movement is not visible to the player... Why would you make your players wait and stare at the screen for nothing?

The thing I personally enjoy the most in these type of games is the leveling and character management system. I just love seeing my guys advance, get new skill and stats, better gear etc. Unfortunately, this was also ruined by a stat restricted system that forces you to spend vast amounts of gold and several campaign turns to learn a new skill. You can't exactly go fight without your leader, and each wasted turn makes it harder for you to complete the time based objectives the game gives you.

If I sound needlessly harsh it's because I am tired. Tired of seeing developers time and time again waste golden opportunities by taking something with good concept and great theme and then, rather than improving on the original games while staying as faithful as possible, proceed to s*it all over it and give birth to an abomination only Clan Moulder packlords could appreciate.

reviewText:
This has the potential to be a really good game - in some ways it is a good game already - and it may well become one in all ways. If it does i'll certainly change my review to positive, but at the moment, despite a lot that's good in the game design, good atmosphere and good graphics, there are some annoying design flaws and some basic necessities lacking.

If i could i'd have given it a neutral review at the moment, as a i like a lot of things about it, despite being frustrated by several others, but Steam only allows positive or negative.

The atmosphere is good and some design choices are good too - e.g being unarmoured gives less protection from damage if you're hit, but it also gives a higher chance of dodging attacks - and of climbing and jumping successfully.

The AI is pretty good - not perfect - but about as good as I am at any rate.

However some other design choices do not work.

The amount of equipment characters can lose from being knocked out in battle is excessive, as are some of the permanent injuries. You can play say 8 missions with a warband in the single player campaign, win 7 heavily, then lose so much equipment from one defeat that your campaign is over.

(EDIT : Above not entirely true - once you've played enough of the game, even if you lose campaigns, you get Veteran Skills for all your warbands, which include some giving you a 5% chance over so much time of getting free armour, but still, armour is rarer than it should be imo)

This is even more so, as , even if you do have money, the shop frequently has literally nothing to buy in it - and even when it does have anything to buy, sometimes very little, and  rarely much armour.

The penalties for abandoning even a single player campaign mission are often equally campaign-ending. I abandoned one mission and practically my whole gang were injured as a result, even though none had even lost any significant number of hitpoints in the part of the mission i played.

One hero ended up losing an arm, while my only archer developed megalomania, meaning he could no onger use missile weapons - and he was pretty high level at this point.

This is made even worse by the lack of any save game function in for single player campaign - so if you get one disastrous mission you can't reload from before it and try again, you have to start the campaign from scratch with a new warband.

The game has included the variety of set ups from the original tabletop miniatures game, but, while these worked well for the tabletop game, they don't all work in the computer game. For instance when one side is deployed inside buildings in the tabletop game, they can leave them quickly and easily in a single turn. But some of the computer game buildings are confusing mazes that can take a while to get out of at all.

The overhead map you can switch the view to in battles now makes it a bit closer to the tabletop game - but unfortunately the map is sometimes misleading, showing what are actually rows of houses that can't be entered or crossed to look like they are a drop or have gaps them in - and this can result in defeat in some missions because you just can't find how to get half your warband to where the fighting is.

The 'ambush' stance in battles allows for ambushers" to "ambush" while standing in the open. I've even had enemies run up to within two feet of me in plain sight in the open

reviewText:
The game has the potential of being good, but fails. The AI behaves very poorly and the designers compensates by giving the AI unit more health and damage as well as let them know the placement of your units. This makes the game even more random than the dice based concept does. Battles are still easy to win but it just means that every odd game you loose units because the AI is able to bring multiple hero units to focus the same (usually) lower level hero unit that you have hiding in a building out of sight. Once knocked down it will eventually end up suffering an injury which completely ruins the build you were going for (ranged unit cannot use ranged weapons, spellcaster pays double points for casting spells etc.).
Randomness to this degree (might) work in tabletop games where you play a game an evening with friends, but not when you are playing a campain" with the intend of levelling and progressing your units.
Story mode is not worth much and consistest mainly of large blocks of text paired with missions that drag on forever.
All in all there are better turn-based strategy games to play than this."

reviewText: This game is too hard.  The original Mordheim (and Necromunda etc like it) were tabletop games where both sides were humans and most importantly 'Used the same dice'.  Here the computer has one loaded set against yours.  Before people cry 'RNG' I have seen that in other games - even games based on other tabletop games by Games Workshop, and at least its generally fair even if you have a bad game sometimes.  But here when my character misses 3 '90% hits' in a row, and his one hits with 3 '60% hits' in a row - and it happens almost every game - I call that cheating not 'RNG'.  When this happens in 'every battle' then it goes beyond a joke, and so I have decided to uninstall this game today.  A shame really - I enjoyed the seeming difficulty to start with.  But there a difference between a difficult game (which I enjoy) and a cheating opponent (which I do not) - and there are better ways for a developer to make a game hard than loaded dice!  Not even remotely recommended - 2/10
