reviewText:
I so wanted to like this game, but as it stands I cannot recommend the game. The graphics are good, as is the combat system.

I did make a negative review after 18 hours play, but decided to delete that and give the game a second chance as it is quite addictive. However I wish that I hadn't bothered deleting the review.

All that you read about the broken and biased RNG is true and then some.

Warband characters who have 80%+ chance to hit miss 80%+ of the time. Whilst AI characters hit your characters 80%+ of the time and a high percentage of these hits are critical kills or stuns. Your hits do minimal damage, with very few criticals.

The vast bias toward AI characters can in no way be attributed to stats and buffs or debuffs. The obvious imbalance is too great for this.

If this were anything to do with gambling the developers would be guilty of cheating by using loaded dice.

In the 92 hours I played so far I have formed and deleted over 100 warbands, most of them during the first or second mission, because they were put out of action so easily by the AI warband, with resultant loss of items, and treatment costs and cost of replacing items and characters which were out of action or died.

Out of action characters get wounds which need treatment. This treatment is expensive and far out weighs any loot or gold gained from a mission. It quickly comes to the point that you can nolonger continue as you can't treat out of action characters and you can't replace them. If your leader is out of action you cannot continue untill treatment is finished or they are replaced by another leader. With obvious loss of already scarce funds.

On the subject of costs, the costs of training a character are prohibitive. On the one occasion where I did get a warband to a decent level I had characters with 6 skill points which could not be used as the costs were unaffordable. Most charcters had got to their maximum stats too as it took so many missions to get anywhere.

In the end this warband was deleted at the library mission still in the first chapter, as charaters were either so badly injured, lost limbs or died that continuing was not possible.

At high levels the costs of replacing characters who die is so expensive as to be pretty much impossible. This means you can only get low level replacemants who are put out of action the first mission they enter.

The mercenary warlock is a waist of time and money. His single spell, blinding light, is ineffectual. He is easily killed and not worth the expense of treatment. I soon fired the one I had.

Game load times are appaling. Go make a drink, finish it and go make another. If you are lucky the mission may have loaded. Deployment and AI movemnt also gets increasingly lengthy as the warband members increase in numbers.

I will probably continue playing in the hope that the RNG issues are fixed, but I won't hold my breath on that score having seen the number of comments on this area without improvemnts being made.

I cannot recomend the game until the RNG issues are fixed.

Edit:- 18/01/16

I forgot to mention the constant freezes and crashes. Usually when any sort of action is initiated. Climbing, jumping down, attacking and triggering traps. I have plenty of games which are far more graphic intensive and I do not have issues with them.

The crashes are particularly anoying because of the lengthy load times.

Edit 8/2/16

Gave it another chance.
Appalingly bad game balance. It seems that not only is the game heavily balanced towords AI warband strength, and hit abilities and defence abilities, the AI warband does not have a limit on the nuimber of characters in the warband or the distance each character can move.
Just deleted yet another warbdand after 33 games getting nowhere. Hadn't even got as far as the temple mission (second main mission). Warband at full compliment with most characters max'd out on ability points, was overwelmingly outnumbered by characters who could move from one side of the map to the other in one move, and had multiple hits per character.
I did have the disadvantage of 3 one eyed characters, 2 of them being archers. The ability to gain gold is so limited, and the expenses involved replacing higher level characters so excessive, as to make replacing even one of these 3 impossible.
All my characters were put out of action and belongings removed. This left me with all characters needing days of recovery with no weapons, and no money to replace lost weapons.


I have now deleted this pile of game from my pc, as it's obvious balance issues are not going to be fixed. It has become far to tedious spending hours getting absolutely nowhere, because the game is so heavily biased in favour of the AI warband. Unfortunately a refund is even less likely than a balance fix.

reviewText:
Let's start this off by saying I like this game, I may play it in the future if the DLC coming out for it looks good and they fix some of the balance problems.

Let's start with the good and the great.
-Level design
Good, the custom maps are great and the random maps are good except when the occasional glitch happens.

-Enviroment
Great, mutated corpses blowing bubbles of blood, giant mutated bodies suspending the roof of a tower, captures the atmosphere of Mordheim.

-Management
Really enjoyable management making and customizing a warband is great fun.

-RPG elements
Also great, in depth, with lots of build options, if the game was more balanced and less decided with a coin toss I could see myself spending hours making builds.

On to the negatives.

-RNG
The RNG is not right, this has been echoed and repeated by almost everyone, there are less then 20 people I have talked to who can defend the RNG.
You can test it yourself, get CoP there leader gets a spell with 85% to succeed. Cast it a hundred times, realize that it only works HALF THE TIME. Casting chance has no modifiers, int doesn't increase it, armor and weapon enchants doesn't increase it either.
Its the best way to test RNG.

-Implementation of the RNG.
This is my second problem, lets say I'm deluded, I'm just a bad player who makes bad rolls scapegoats. Even with the RNG working as it should the prevelance of it is unbearable.
Its random when you get a shipment, you can fulfill the shipment just to have once come in the very next day, usually demanding 50 pnds more.
Secondly the difficulty of the missions you go on AND the deployment is also random, so you can have 10 days to fulfill a shipment only to have awful rolls that makes it so 6/10 days you have are up against tough or brutal missions all with the chance for your group to be scattered.
Which means you will end up in a house with one of your units getting gangbanged before you ever get a chance to move.
Mutations are random as well which is fine MUTATIONS SHOULD BE RANDOM, however mutations should not be the saem for EVERY MUTANT.
The first Mutant you have excess to has 5 points in ballistic while only 3 in melee.
However you are almost gauranteed to get an arm mutation making any ranged weapons unusable so why the hell do we have a mutant that is your only hero option in the beginning with 2 extra points that could be anywhere else except ballistic?
The game is full of stuff like this but more on that later.

Ultimately with the RNG you will find yourself ♥♥♥♥ed regardless of how well you play, I have lost one match ONE! However I still often restart with a new warband because of being forced into a bad spot by the RNG.
For example I have had my leader unit roll Wrath of Tzeentech TWICE in two matches, both on casting WoD and wearing a blue amulet to avoid this.
First ended with a light wound rest for two days, the other a near death experience which takes 5 days.
My shipment was in 7 days so I had only two days to make the shipment.
So whatever I have only a couple more clusters to deliver to make my shipment.
So I check the missions, I have the choice of Brutal and Tough missions all with scattered deployment for one side or both sides.
With only two days I decide I have to take on so I choose the Tough mission, and surprise surprise my luck gets two of my units basically sorrounded by enemies that get taken out before their turns because of their lower initiave.
Which is the point I uninstalled the game.

-Balance
Good god the balance is so poorly figured out no wonder multiplayer is dead.
Skaven for example are king, they get 3 meters extra movement, which means they can outrange your charges and ambushes even when you have Bullcharge the AI still gets to ambush or charge you on even, you cannot do this.

CoP is the weakest group as they are based entirely on RNG and have weirdly built heroes.
I already brought up the weird mutant with pointless points in ballistic.
Now let me bring up the possessed, absolutely worthless unit, Fear checks are almost always passed by the AI meaning he rarely gets the buff that would make him usefull.
He has awful dodge unless points are sunk into it which gimps him in other ways. He is incredibly squishy, only clothing allowed.
He has incredibly low DPS, only two attacks on start because he is always dual wielding thanks to bracers/mutations only which means he is always going to cost another OP for an attack.
LOSING AN ARM MAKES HIM BETTER, honestly, if he gets his arm chopped off he gets a bonus in dodge, initiave bonus and can make three hits a turn.
So in summary to squishy to tank, not enough DPS to be a glass cannon.

-NPC handicaps
These are the worst.
Skaven which should be a squishy race with high movement is now a terror because the NPC get a large chunk of extra health often given more health then your own units!
Their leadership will also rival yours regardless of what your focusing on.
It completely skews the feeling of progression.
How am I a high leadership warband when EVERY warband has higher leadership regardless of stats invested?
Why do I invest into alertness when my units can't ever break ahead of the enemies initiave?
You will never have the option for Easy missions, Normal missions is you still facing enemies with higher stats, health, leadership and initiave.


In summary.
I'm at a loss with this game, I really like its mechanics, I really like how it plays.
However the poor balance that hasn't been fixed, the dead multiplayer, the boosted NPC enemies, the constant RNG ♥♥♥♥ery.
When I sit down and begin a match while the game loads I just think to myself, why don't I just flip a coin and leave it at that?

reviewText:
Just to preface with 'gaming experience' in the 'Warhammer' setting...
1. Warhammer 40k fan (Rogue Trader) - shows me age...
2. Warmaster Fan - shows I enjoyed more than just the flashy Space Marine or the gritty Black Orc...

Really wanted this to be something good - as in 'a successful port'.

Yea...

So, as a port its not bad.

Pros:
It's a port of the mini game

Cons:
Create warband.  Warband does so-so.  Warband instakilled in match against a basic opponent that just rolls them....aaaaand....not enough starting money to reliably rebuild.  And, this is only day two?

If more starting money was provided to rebuild a constant battle of warbad attrition = no thanks.

The balance is off plain and simple.

Should you OP through the game = no.
Should you have to struggle through a game = yes.
Should you be bent over a barrel every single game = no.

There really needs to be a flat hand versus a thumbs up and down in the rating section because a thumbs down really isn't fair - to be honest...

As an IT person what the devs did was actually really cool...it's the balance that's way off; and, not in the building but in the battles.  Yes, yes, yes - the setting is supposed to be brutal but I should not be missing 85% chance hits four times in a row in matches that are right next to each other.  That should be something of a statistical outlier.

Would I recommend this game - no.
And, that really pains me to say that as I understand the business model and the 'need to eat'.

Balance the math behind the scene a bit and get back to me.

Other than that - bravo devs!

reviewText:
I really want to enjoy this game, and I'll probably keep playing it now and then, but it's very, very hard to recommend, especially at full price. On sale it's much, much safer for your wallet, though not on your blood pressure, it will suffer and if you're anything like me you'll break a keyboard or two while realizing that.

It is an excellent strategy game. As a warband within the walls of Mordheim you are tasked by superiors to retrieve a substance froma meteor that's all over the city, while combating rival bands and improving your troops.

It's strategy, so you'll move units around a battlefield and combat and pick up items and resources, pay tribute to your benifactor, and upgrade your team. However, given my complaints, it might be better to call it a rouge-like strategy.

Your higher ups will demand some wyrdstone, you will go out to complete the order, and get paid for it. RNG will kill your team. You will try to hire more people. You will run out of money. You will be stuck without money and without units and your superior will still demand more until game over. Over and over and over again. Plan to fail in the face of an awful system of routine pain and suffering if you want to get to the delicious center where all the excellent strategy and gameplay lie.

An auto save system keeps you from save scumming, which would be a mode in another game, allowing for a variety of people to enjoy the game any way they want. As it stands, it serves only to frusterate as men you pay to fight fail and fall over while trying to complete basic plans. A 90% chance to hit is closer to a 50 in the eyes of the RNG gods. Watch people you've put hours of work and skill into die because they were randomly put next to an ogre. Observe nights of effort put to the flame by lucky crit.

Some people are into that, and that's cool, this game will cater to you, and I can reccomend it. The rest of us are left kind of disappointed we spent money on this.

reviewText:
I really wanted to recommend this game.  Let's start with the good: it looks amazing, and does a strong job of capturing the feel of despair that permeates the Warhammer universe.  I approached the game assuming it would be a rogue-like, and on my first playthrough everything clicked well for 8-9 battles and I had a great time.  I won most, I lost a couple.  Eventually, my warband lost a fight badly, my Leader and my Hero both suffered perma-death, so I rolled-up a new warband.

I've rolled up four new warbands since then, and never made it past the second mission.

Because the AI is so bad, the Devs game it a huge number of advantages.  Some are blatant, others I'm inferring based on AI behavior.

1) In anything that should be an even match-up, it takes twice as many hits for a PC to defeat an AI than it does an AI to defeat a PC.  If the enemy leader runs up out of nowhere and smacks your leader, you will lose about 1/3 of your health in one shot.  When you counterattack, you'll do about 1/6 of his health in total damage.  Also, archers are incredibly underpowered, and only do about 10-15% damage to an enemy.  It's pretty much the same for minions.  This means that in a one-on-one fight, you are generally guaranteed to lose.  The only way to defeat the enemy is to mass combat power on an isolated enemy.  Which brings us to point 2...

2) It's often impossible to mass combat power, because the game frequently scatters your characters' starting positions all over the map.  You will often start with at least one character alone and surrounded by enemies.  Even if you have all your characters make a beeline for a central location, it will take a minimum of 2-3 rounds to consolidate.  In that time period, at least one or two of your characters will probably be dead, because the AI never seems to have a problem bringing 2-3 characters into contact with an isolated character by round 2.

3) The AI always seems to know the shortest path through level geometry.  If I have archers stationed at a high point raining down arrows, the AI can always find a path to get a melee character into close combat in one round.  Meanwhile , a human player without perfect knowledge of the geometry may spend several rounds trying to find a path up to an enemy archer.

4) The only real source of money in the game is Wyrdstone, and you must collect it constantly to please your patron to keep the game from ending.  However, the enemy generally seems to have no interest in Wyrdstone, and makes a beeline for your characters, forcing you to spend all your efforts fighting until one side routs.  If your rout, you receive no Wyrdstone.  If you win, you receive a very small fraction of the total Wyrdstone remaining on the map.

The one time the enemy IS interested in Wyrdstone is when one of your characters has collected some and is running it back to your wagon.  The AI seems to know which character has Wyrdstone and focuses all effort on bringing down that character to prevent you from collecting any.

5) There is no difficulty setting.  I understand it's supposed to be hardcore, but even after paying for scouts, my difficulty options for battle on Day 2 are frequently a combination of Brutal and Deadly.  In order to make your required payments to your patron, you need to win the overwhelming majority of battles.  Because of the low Wyrdstone collection rate, even the battles you win provide very little Wyrdstone.  Check out the achievements on who has even gotten as far as completing Chapter 1 for each of the factions.  The highest is currently the Mercenaries with 3%.  It's one thing if your game demands intelligent play and well-thought tactics.  But this game is frequently over before you take your first turn.

Verdict: This could be a great game if they smooth the learning curve a bit, stop the deployment stupidity, and reduce the AI's stat advantage.  There's a great game hiding in there.  The people who praise the game in its current form generally talk about how easy it is to exploit the AI.  If the only way to win is through AI exploitation, this is a poorly designed game.

reviewText: It is turn-based tactical fighting, squad management game in the warhammer world.  If that sounds good to you than pick it up!  You will not be disapointed.  This game keeps all the stategy element of any other tactical game but instead of moving big clunky squads around you move individual warriors around.  Each warrior levels up, you can pick customizable skills and customize their gear.  As you go you unlock more troops/heroes and troop/heroes types.  Which can be a lot of planning if you OCD about your character builds like me.  You start to get attached to your troops but they can get injured or die which adds a true sense of risk to the game.   The factions are interesting and I love that they put skaven as a playable faction.\n\nThe maps are designed well and the control work well.  To maintain your warband you have to be constantly farming warpstone around the field which makes you split your troop into fighters and gathers most of the time.  The layout is a bit hard to see for the map.  It is hard to tell if an area is raise or if you can climb something until you run your character there but that might be intended.
